item.title: The best catch ever? I'll drink to that! Baseball fan who had her hands full with a beer and mobile phone takes ball in her cup - before celebrating moment by downing it
item.description: Holding a mobile phone in one hand and a pint of beer in the other, one game-goer somehow managed to catch a high ball after the batter sliced a shot backwards from the plate.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlanta Braves thrashed the San Diego Padres, 14-1, at Petco Park on Wednesday night but the star of the show was in the stands.

Holding a mobile phone in one hand and a beer in the other, one Padres fan, identified as Gabby DiMarco by MLB.com, somehow managed to catch a high foul ball after the batter sliced a shot backwards from the plate.

The ball landed in the woman's pint, which remarkably remained in her hand.

Beer — and baseball — served to your seat at @Padres games 🍺⚾️ pic.twitter.com/zCh3HjeUyD

— Petco Park (@PetcoPark) June 6, 2018

Undeterred by the presence of the ball in her plastic cup, she then proceeded to down the remains of the beverage while lapping up the applause of her fellow baseball fans.

She later told MLB.com: 'It bounced from behind me, I was trying to catch it, and it landed in my cup.' 

Something very similar happened at the Masters in Augusta earlier this year when a shot from Jason Day hit a tree before bouncing off a patron's shoulder and into the cup of beer in his hand.

Instead of reaching into his pint, the man chugged the remains of the drink before handing the ball to Day. 

Day was given a free drop as close to the incident as possible but went on to bogey the hole.

item.title: England stars fly into brutal collisions ahead of opening South Africa Test... as Eddie Jones's squad go in search of first win in five matches
item.description: Despite the large number of injuries suffered at England training camps under Eddie Jones, players held nothing back as Brad Shields continued his integration into the squad by tussling with Billy Vunipola.
item.content:encoded:
England players were spotted flying into brutal collisions on Wednesday as they stepped up their preparations ahead of the first Test against South Africa this weekend.

Players are expected to feel the full force of the Springboks at Ellis Park on Saturday as Eddie Jones's side go in search of a first win in five matches following an abject 2018 so far.

Despite the large number of injuries suffered at England training camps during Jones' tenure, players looked to be holding nothing back as Brad Shields continued his integration into the squad by tussling with Billy Vunipola. 


ENGLAND'S SOUTH AFRICA TOUR SCHEDULE

First Test - June 9 (Ellis Park, Johannesburg)

Second Test - June 16 (Free State Stadium,  Bloemfontein)

Third Test - June 23 (Newlands, Cape Town) 

Shields, the Hurricanes captain and blindside flanker, flew from New Zealand to join up with England for the first time after being included in the squad for the three-Test series against the Springboks.

At least 18 players including five Bath players have picked up injuries during England practices under Jones, but that did not prevent Shields from using all his strength to over power his fellow forward as the squad took part in a test of strength.

Jamie George was also pictured putting maximum effort into a tackling practice while Danny Cipriani took the brunt of a collision during the hard-hitting session.

Owen Farrell, George Ford and Jonny May also had their work cut out and were among those pictured taking part in an agility drill while simultaneously holding enormous horizontal weights.

The squad also looked to be fine tuning a number of their offensive drills with Farrell and Ford working in tandem as they possibly will be on Saturday.

The fly-half and inside centre combination were snapped running through plans that they hope will stifle the South African defence.

England face a difficult task when the return to Ellis Park on Saturday, the same venue they were beaten 36-27 six years ago.

Back in 2012, under Stuart Lancaster, England were brutally battered in the Johannesburg venue where Jones' side have to front up this weekend.

Joe Marler, Ben Youngs, Chris Robshaw and Owen Farrell - captain on this tour - are the only survivors from that game and will be keen to exact revenge.

item.title: Lowdown on Brazil ahead of the World Cup: Sportsmail assesses where Tite's side stand ahead of trip to Russia
item.description: Brazil are one of the favourites to win the World Cup in Russia this summer. Tite's side play their final warm-up game on Sunday ahead of their bid to win a sixth World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
Brazil are one of the favourites to win the World Cup in Russia this summer.

Tite's side play their final warm-up game against Austria on Sunday ahead of their bid to win a sixth World Cup. 

Sportsmail assesses where they stand ahead of their trip to the tournament. 


What’s the latest with Neymar?

The Paris Saint-Germain forward played his first game in three months after he injured his metatarsal playing for the Ligue 1 side against Marseille in February. 

For a time, his participation in Russia was in genuine doubt, but he came on as a substitute at Anfield against Croatia last Sunday as one of Tite's half-time changes and 98 days after he sustained the injury in France.

He made a goal-scoring return in Brazil's 2-0 win in the friendly match in Liverpool. 

Perhaps worryingly, he still has issues with his foot.

Neymar admitted after the game he is 'only 80 per cent fit' and showed fans the wrapping on his injured foot on Instagram. 

Prior to leaving Brazil for a camp at Tottenham’s training ground last week, he said: ‘Physically I am well, my foot is fine. I am adapting in a few things. I still feel some discomfort, but it is not something that will trouble me.’

Once in London he said: ‘(I’m) not 100 per cent yet. But that comes with time. It is normal that I have this fear of making complete movements. Let's take it easy, there are still many days until the opener and I will be 100 per cent then.’

It’s not an ideal situation.

Assuming he is fit, what would the team look like?

The beauty of Tite’s squad is its depth. It is truly immense.

There is a still a degree of uncertainty over what direction Tite will take in attack. In last Thursday’s training, he used Philippe Coutinho and Gabriel Jesus up front.

That being said, Tite is expected to go with a 4-3-3 in Russia and during training in Rio de Janeiro earlier last week he was using Willian alongside Neymar and Jesus.

Midfielder Renato Augusto has an injury to his right knee and missed the game against Croatia, but his position appears in some jeopardy longer term, with Tite said to be open to sacrificing Augusto in favour of using Coutinho in a deeper role.

With Willian, Neymar, Jesus, Coutinho, Roberto Firmino and Douglas Costa as attacking options, Tite will likely have the most sparkling frontline at the competition.

He has midfield stability from Real Madrid’s Casemiro and Manchester City’s Fernandinho – Manchester United's new signing Fred could yet come in - and a good defence in Danilo, Marquinhos, Miranda and Marcelo. Thiago Silva was in the practice side ahead of Marquinhos last Thursday but could be looking at a place on the bench at the World Cup.

In goal, they have competition between Roma’s brilliant keeper Alisson, who is wanted by Real Madrid and Liverpool, and Ederson of Manchester City.

In all, it might just be the strongest side and squad in Russia.

Potential World Cup line up: Alisson; Danilo, Marquinhos, Miranda, Marcelo; Casemiro, Coutinho, Paulinho; Willian, Neymar, Gabriel Jesus.

Is there a weakness?

Right back. Dani Alves’ knee injury has set up a battle between Manchester City's Danilo or Fagner of Corinthians for the spot.

What is their form like?

Under Tite it has been excellent and they have brought back the flair since Dunga’s departure in June 2016. Dunga left after Brazil failed to reach the knockout stage of the Copa America for the first time since 1987 and with the team sixth in the South American World Cup qualifying group.

Since Tite came in, they have won 16 of his 20 games, with only one defeat. The team scored 30 goals in their final 12 qualifiers compared to 11 in the first six.

A World Cup group comprised of Switzerland, Costa Rica and Serbia should pose no serious problems.

Who is the star man?

Neymar, of course. In 84 matches since his debut in 2010, he has 54 goals - fourth on Brazil's all-time list behind Romario (55), Ronaldo (62) and Pele (77).

What are they saying?

There’s a degree of cautious optimism, typified by Willian who said: ‘I think we will get on well in the World Cup. It's hard to pinpoint favourites. There are four or five teams, including Brazil, that can reach the same level.

‘The World Cup is a tournament that practically does not allow errors, especially in the final. From the last World Cup (and their 7-1 semi-final humiliation against Germany), we've learned the good and the bad sides of the tournament, which was the moment we were eliminated. This time my expectation is that we can experience only the good side.

‘Of course it's in my head to win the title. This is my biggest dream, but I know the difficulties we will face in order to achieve this goal.’

item.title: Home sweet home! England one of two World Cup nations to have entire 23-man squad playing in domestic league
item.description: England are one of two nations in the 2018 World Cup that has every player playing at home in the main domestic league with group rivals Belgium only able to boast one star back playing at home,
item.content:encoded:
Gareth Southgate has travelled up and down the country in recent seasons, scouting players and deciding who he wanted in his 23-man squad for the World Cup in Russia.

But it now appears the Three Lions boss had it easier than others with every member of the final 23 plying their trade in England.

England are one of two nations in the 2018 World Cup that has every player playing at home in the main domestic league with group rivals Belgium only able to boast young midfielder Leander Dendonker at Anderlecht.


Roberto Martinez is fortunate that his biggest stars descended on mass to the Premier League with Eden Hazard, Kevin De Bruyne, Romelu Lukaku, Thibaut Courtois, Mousa Dembele, Toby Alderweireld and Jan Vertonghen all regulars for their clubs in England. 

Admittedly, there are only a handful of England stars testing themselves abroad - Jadon Sancho at Borrusia Dortmund one example - but none were close to squad selection this time round.

Of the 32 nations competing in Russia this summer, Sweden and Senegal are the only countries to have not one player playing their club football in their homeland. 

A detailed analysis reveals that only six countries can enter double figures with Saudi Arabia the other to get a full bill of 23 while Russia amassed 21.

Spain's group is La Liga heavy with goalkeepers David De Gea and Pepe Reina joining Cesar Azpilicueta, Nacho Monreal and Bayern Munich's Thiago Alcantara in pushing themselves elsewhere.  

But will England's geographical continuity strike a chord this summer is a question that remains unanswered. 

Southgate's side begin the tournament on June 18 against Tunisia before facing Panama and Belgium to conclude their group.

item.title: Manchester United add £52m Fred to their list of Brazilians... but will he be a samba star or an Old Trafford flop like Kleberson or Rodrigo Possebon?
item.description: Manchester United are poised to seal the £52million signing of Brazil midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk. He will become the seventh Brazilian to play for the club.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United are poised to seal the £52million signing of Brazil midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk.

Jose Mourinho moved quickly to sign Fred on a five-year contract as United pipped their neighbours Manchester City to the 25-year-old's signature.

He will become the seventh Brazilian player in United's history and we take a closer look at the six that came before him here.


 

KLEBERSON

United 2003-2005; 30 appearances, two goals

Sir Alex Ferguson didn't get a whole lot wrong during his time at Manchester United, but the 2003 signing of Jose Kleberson Pereira doesn't reflect well on him with hindsight.

'One of the reasons we sold Seba Veron was because we knew we were getting Kleberson - that shows how highly we regard his talent,' said Fergie when United sealed his £5.93m signing from Atletico Paranaense.

Indeed, what a tumultuous summer 2003 was at Old Trafford. They sold David Beckham to Real Madrid for £25m and Veron to Chelsea for £15m, missed out on another Brazilian, Ronaldinho, but signed a teenager called Cristiano Ronaldo. I wonder what happened to him...

Ferguson's enthusiasm in Kleberson, then 24, wasn't misplaced. He had come from nowhere to become a starter in Luiz Felipe Scolari's Brazilian World Cup winners in 2002 and in the final with Germany set up one of Ronaldo's goals.

Regarded as an industrious and tough-tackling midfielder, Kleberson had initially attracted the attention of Leeds United in that World Cup summer but refused to move to England without his 16-year-old fiancee.

The delay allowed Man United to pounce 12 months later but he never lived up to Ferguson's big build-up, suffered an injury in only his second game and made just 20 Premier League appearances over two seasons.

United cut their losses and sold him to Besiktas for a third of the cost in 2005 and Kleberson's career never came close to scaling such heights again.

He is now the under-12s coach at MLS side Philadelphia Union.

 

ANDERSON

United 2007-2015; 181 appearances, nine goals

Anderson was that rare thing - a Brazilian success story in the Premier League. And he became something of a cult hero with United fans during his eight years at Old Trafford.

The midfielder had a sunshine personality off the field - always smiling, amusing his team-mates with his early efforts to learn English, blasting out samba music and living in Cristiano Ronaldo's house for his first seven months in Manchester.

On the field, he was dedicated and committed, admitting in an interview that he played through injuries for 'God of football' Ferguson. He always seemed to play especially well in grudge matches against Arsenal.

His Old Trafford career was something of a slow-burner. Signed for £20m from Porto in 2007, he had to compete against the likes of Paul Scholes and Michael Carrick for a spot in the team.

Yet he ended his first season as a European champion. Often forgotten in memories of John Terry's slip and Nicolas Anelka's fateful miss was that in between them Anderson hammered home his penalty.

While at no point an automatic pick in his eight years with United, Anderson still managed 181 appearances for the club, winning four league titles and a host of other medals. Injuries often prevented him playing more.

Having fallen out of favour under Louis van Gaal, Anderson, capped eight times for the Selecao during his career, returned home to join Internacional.

Still only 30, he is currently without a club.

 

RODRIGO POSSEBON

United 2008-2010; Eight appearances, no goals

Recommended to Ferguson by United's Brazil-based scout John Calvert-Toulmin while he was checking out the Da Silva twins (more of them later), Possebon joined for £3m in January 2008.

United hoped they'd signed the next Brazilian wonderkid and the defensive midfielder started brightly enough, coming on to make his Premier League debut on the opening day of the following season.

But things were never the same after he was injured in a challenge by Middlesbrough's Emanuel Pogatetz in a League Cup fixture the following month. It proved the first of a succession of injury setbacks that blighted his career.

Though he returned and even played enough times to earn a League Cup winner's medal, Possebon didn't make a breakthrough and was loaned out to Braga the following year, making just one appearance.

From there, Possebon rattled through a number of Brazilian clubs without settling and was last spotted at Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam.

Even that wasn't meant to be - a 'back injury and a lack of fitness' was the reason given by the club when he was released in February. Still only 29, it's been a rather sad footballing story for Possebon.

 

RAFAEL DA SILVA

United 2008-2015; 169 appearances, five goals

The Da Silva twins, Rafael and Fabio, were playing full-back on opposite sides of the field for Fluminense when united scout Les Kershaw spotted them in the 2005 Nike Premier Cup in Hong Kong.

He described them as 'two little whippets' to Ferguson because of their seemingly boundless energy and resilience and recommended United sign them. That they did eventually, seeing off competition from Arsenal in the process.

The identical twins were only 17 when they came to Manchester but Ferguson had no hesitation throwing Rafael into the cut and thrust of the Premier League and even the Champions League.

Rafael, unlike his brother, was able to hold down a place in the United team and was highly-regarded by Ferguson, even if it did sometimes lead to confusion.

'It wasn't rare that before training he'd look at me and say: 'Come on, go to the left wing.' When that happened, I used to just look at him. Then he'd go: 'I meant right wing, Rafael!' he recalled of the manager.

Indeed, the only way Fergie could reliably tell them apart was because Fabio was married and wore a wedding ring.

Rafael helped United to Champions League finals in 2009 and 2011, as well as three Premier League titles, the League Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup.

He continued to play under David Moyes and also during the initial months under Louis van Gaal. But after returning from an injury, he couldn't force his way back into the team, Van Gaal dealing with the situation in brutal fashion.

'In his first season, Van Gaal called me to his office and said: 'You can leave.' Rafael revealed recently. 'The meeting lasted one minute. That was it: 'You can leave.'

Rafael has since established himself well at French club Lyon. 

 

FABIO DA SILVA

United 2008-2014; 56 appearances, three goals

Having arrived at United via the same route as his brother, Fabio's competitive debut for the club was delayed by a shoulder injury that required surgery.

He had to wait until January 2009 for his debut, against Tottenham in the fourth round of the FA Cup, but suffered another injury in that very game.

While Fabio invariably impressed when he did get a chance, his United career never gained the same traction as his brothers and by 2012-13 he was out on loan at Queens Park Rangers while Rafael was winning the league.

A red card in United's FA Cup defeat to Swansea in January 2014 convinced Moyes to let him ho and Fabio has since played for Cardiff City and Middlesbrough.

 

ANDREAS PEREIRA

United 2011-present; 13 appearances, one goal

Technically, Fred won't be the only Brazilian on the books at Old Trafford. Andreas Pereira is still a United player, even if the playmaker is among the lesser-spotted around Old Trafford.

Pereira was a PSV Eindhoven starlet when he caught United's eye in the Manchester United Premier Cup back in 2011 and it was a personal visit from Ferguson that persuaded him to sign there instead of Arsenal, Chelsea and Liverpool.

The Belgian-born Brazilian became one of the stars of United's academy, working his way through the ranks before Van Gaal, keen to promote youth, handed him a senior debut in that ignominious 4-0 League Cup loss to MK Dons.

All 13 of Pereira's appearances to date came under the Dutch manager, with Jose Mourinho deciding loan experience would be preferable to kicking around in the reserves.

Consequently, Pereira has spent the last two seasons in Spain, first with Granada and then with Valencia, and he has indeed featured in plenty of matches.

It now remains to be seen whether there's a future for him at United or, as is most likely, he'll seek a new club.

item.title: Three time Moto GP world champion Jorge Lorenzo to join Honda after his compatriot Dani Pedrosa was dropped
item.description: Spain's three times MotoGP world champion Jorge Lorenzo will leave Ducati and join compatriot Marc Marquez in a stellar lineup at the works Honda team next season after signing a two-year deal.
item.content:encoded:
Spain's three times MotoGP world champion Jorge Lorenzo will leave Ducati and join compatriot Marc Marquez in a stellar lineup at the works Honda team next season after signing a two-year deal.

Marquez could be a five times MotoGP world champion by then with the 25-year-old currently 23 points clear at the top of standings after six races.

Honda Racing Corporation (HRC) announced the move in a statement on Wednesday.


'From 2019, Lorenzo will become team mate to four-times MotoGP world champion Marc Marquez: two great champions with great talent and high hopes that will make a stronger team and contribute to the development of HRC,' it said.

The pair are the only riders to win the MotoGP championship since Australian Casey Stoner in 2011 -- Lorenzo in 2012 and 2015 and Marquez in 2013, 2014, 2016 and 2017. Lorenzo was also champion in 2010.

Between them, they have 130 wins and 255 podiums in all categories.

Lorenzo, who won his titles with Yamaha but has struggled to find his form since joining Ducati last year, will replace compatriot Dani Pedrosa in the Repsol Honda lineup.

MOTO GP WORLD CHAMPIONS 

2017 - Marc Marquez (Honda)

2016 - Marc Marquez (Honda)

2015 - Jorge Lorenzo (Yamaha)

2014 - Marc Marquez (Honda)

2013 - Marc Marquez (Honda)

2012 - Jorge Lorenzo (Yamaha) 

2011 - Casey Stoner (Honda)

2010 - Jorge Lorenzo (Yamaha)

The departure of Pedrosa, who has spent his entire grand prix with the Japanese manufacturer since his 125cc debut in 2001, was announced on Tuesday.

Lorenzo's Italian Grand Prix victory at Mugello on Sunday was his first win for Ducati but came too late to make any change in his relationship with the team.

'If the pieces that I needed had arrived much earlier, now I would say to you, 'I stay in Ducati and I have now two or three victories,'' the rider told MotoGP.com after the race.

'But unfortunately, they arrive too late these pieces, and now... I win here, but it's too late, and the next two years I will be with another bike.'

The 31-year-old, who also has two 250cc titles (now Moto2) to his name, looks likely to be replaced at Ducati by Italian Danilo Petrucci, who is currently at the non-factory Pramac Ducati team.

Ducati have already extended the contract of works rider Andrea Dovizioso, last year's overall runner-up.

item.title: Australia call up Tolu Latu in place of the injured Jordan Uelese for Ireland
item.description: With Tatafu Polota-Nau rested for the series, Uelese had been the most experienced hooker in the squad with his two appearances off the bench last year before he suffered an ACL rupture.
item.content:encoded:
Australia have called up hooker Tolu Latu to their squad for Saturday's first Test against Ireland in Brisbane after Jordan Uelese was sidelined for the rest of the season due to a knee injury.

With Tatafu Polota-Nau rested for the series, Uelese had been the most experienced hooker in the squad with his two appearances off the bench last year before he suffered an ACL rupture playing for the Melbourne Rebels last weekend.

The other hookers in the original 33 - former Sydney garbage collectors Brandon Paenga-Amosa and Folau Fainga'a - are both uncapped.

Latu, who won four caps in 2016, was already training with the squad protectively and his international experience earned him the nod ahead of Anaru Rangi.

'Right now he's our most-capped hooker in Australia, so he's got that little bit of experience playing in the big match atmosphere,' Australia coach Michael Cheika said in Brisbane.

'Anaru Rangi has had a really good season with Melbourne too so he's definitely not out of the equation. I'm just keen for the two uncapped hookers to have a little experience around.'


Latu was included in the squad for last year's June internationals but did not get on the pitch, with Cheika suggesting he was not fit enough.

The Tongan-born 25-year-old has played only four matches for the New South Wales Waratahs in Super Rugby this season, all off the bench.

'He's been out of favour at the Tahs for a lot of the year and he's coming back into favour a little,' Cheika added.

'His two or three games he's played, I think he's had a good impact and he's been excellent since he's been in camp.

'He'll be banking on his last few games of form but also his previous games for the Wallabies and I'm sure he'll do well.'

Cheika will name his squad for the first of three Tests against the Six Nation champions on Thursday.

item.title: Barcelona 'ask Monaco about £79m France star Thomas Lemar amid Chelsea and Atletico Madrid interest'
item.description: Barcelona have stepped up their pursuit of France star Thomas Lemar by asking Monaco to name their price for the forward, with reports in Spain claiming a deal could be struck for £79m.
item.content:encoded:
Barcelona have stepped up their pursuit of France star Thomas Lemar by asking Monaco to name their price for the forward.

And reports in Spain claim that any deal for the 22-year-old will set the Catalan giants back by £79million.

Lemar has emerged as one of the hottest prospects in world football and was a target for Arsenal and Liverpool last summer.


But Sport report that Barcelona have now moved towards the front of the queue for the Frenchman's signature.

They also claim that Chelsea and Atletico Madrid will rival Barca in an effort to prise him away from the south of France.

Lemar was a prominent member of Monaco's charge towards the Champions League semi-finals in 2017 in his breakout season.

But he struggled to replicate that form last year amid a succession of injury problems.

He found the back of the net just three times in 35 appearances last season.

Despite a struggle for consistency he has been named by Didier Deschamps in France's 23-man squad for the World Cup.

item.title: Sports minister Tracey Crouch claims all-seater stadia is the best option for football fans despite government suggesting there will be a review of legislation banning them
item.description: Sports minister Tracey Crouch has insisted in the past two days that she believes all-seater stadia are the best option for football fans
item.content:encoded:
Sports minister Tracey Crouch has insisted in the past two days that she believes all-seater stadia is the best option for football fans - despite Government officials indicating that there will be a review of legislation banning them.

Crouch delivered her views in a letter on Monday to Labour MP Liz McInnes, who had asked her about a return to standing on the behalf of a Manchester City supporters' association in her constituency.

All-seaters are 'the best means to ensure the safety and security of fans,' Crouch told McInnes.


Labour are positioning themselves as the party with conviction about considering a return to safe standing, which polls suggest would be a hugely popular move among fans.

Shadow sports minister Dr Rosena Allin-Khan will meet 40 supporters' trusts at Westminster on Wednesday to discuss the issue and said on Tuesday that she had canvassed the opinions of more than 5,000 supporters from more than 200 supporters' trusts.

The review of legislation which Crouch's department has promised is likely to consider how bar code ticket technology and CCTV have dramatically reduced the potential for overcrowding, since all-seaters were made obligatory for English football's top two tiers, in 1994.

'The possibility of any stadium or part of it having more people than they say they have is now minimal,' said Jon Darch, operator of the Safe Standing Roadshow which campaigns for safe standing areas.

Crouch could allow safe standing without back-tracking on her commitment to all-seater stadia. 

The new sports ground safety 'bible' - known as the 'Green Guide' - is expected to include 'rail seat' safe standing technology within its definition of seating, when its latest new edition is published in the autumn. 

The Green Guide has not been updated for 10 years. Crouch could claim she is going along with the advice of the safety experts who have compiled it.

item.title: 'Stick to football, Sterling': Dele Alli captures hilarious moment as his England pal Raheem is hit in the face by a basketball at the arcade
item.description: Dele Alli has called for Raheem Sterling to stick to his day job after capturing his hilarious gaffe at the arcades. The duo were out and about as they tried to unwind ahead of the World Cup in Russia next week.
item.content:encoded:
Dele Alli has called for Raheem Sterling to stick to his day job after capturing his hilarious gaffe at the arcades.

With the World Cup just around the corner, some of the England squad are doing their best to unwind ahead of their trip to Russia.

After boasting about his basketball skills, Sterling was left red-faced after a ball caught him on the nose, filmed for all to see on Tuesday afternoon.


Ahead of the game with Costa Rica on Wednesday evening, the Manchester City star looked calm and relaxed as he practised his jump-shot, with team-mate Dele filming on from afar.

As he successfully scored his first two shots, the 23-year-old appears to get ahead of himself as his third goes horribly awry and hits the frame of the arcade machine.

Without having time to react, the ball bounces back towards Sterling and hits him square in the face, much to the delight of Dele and Co behind the camera.

Like any true friend would in the same situation, Dele proceeds to upload the embarrassing moment to his Instagram where all 3.5 million of his followers could watch Sterling's gaffe. 

Sterling will be hoping to redeem himself for the hilarious gaffe when England play at Elland Road on Thursday evening.

item.title: Marcus Edwards 'wants to leave Tottenham this summer' as teenager once compared to Lionel Messi seeks first-team football
item.description: Ahead of his Tottenham debut in 2016, Pochettino said of Edwards: 'The qualities — it's only looks, his body and the way that he plays — remember a little bit from the beginning of Messi.'
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham teenager Marcus Edwards wants to secure a summer move away.

The 19-year-old, who was once compared to Lionel Messi by Mauricio Pochettino, has only played two senior matches to date — a 15-minute cameo for Spurs in a 5-0 League Cup win over Gillingham in 2016 and an even shorter appearance for Norwich during a disappointing loan spell in the 2017-18 season.

According to The Guardian, Tottenham still believe in the attacking midfielder's potential but the player himself is said to want immediate first-team football, which is unlikely to be on offer in the short term in north London.

Edwards has fallen off the radar somewhat since Pochettino likened him to Barcelona's main man.

Speaking ahead of his Spurs debut in 2016, Pochettino said of Edwards: 'The qualities — it's only looks, his body and the way that he plays — remember a little bit from the beginning of Messi.

'He's small, he's left-footed, I remember a little bit (Erik) Lamela when he was at River Plate, remember he had long hair, when he was 14, 15 years old, there is a lot of videos on YouTube that you can see, that he took the ball, didn't give a pass and shot straight away.


'He is a very good prospect and potentially he can be a top player, but we need to be patient and tell him that he has a lot of talent, enough talent to be a top player, a great player.

'But now it's how he builds his future, that's very important. And it's our responsibility to tell him.'

Pochettino spoke then of patience, but it appears Edwards himself is now running low on it. Edwards has two years left to run on his current contract.

item.title: 'Come on England!': Mourinho tips Three Lions to pip Belgium in group and seal Poland tie as he reveals World Cup predictions (including the hosts after taking £1.7m of Moscow money)
item.description: The Manchester United manager has predicted all group stage scenarios ahead of the World Cup in Russia, which kicks off when the hosts face Saudi Arabia in Moscow next week.
item.content:encoded:
England will beat Belgium to top spot in Group G and set up a winnable last-16 clash with Poland, so claims Jose Mourinho.

Mourinho is teaming up with Kremlin-backed TV channel RT to work as their main pundit at the World Cup and will pocket £1.7million despite spending just four days in Moscow at the start of the tournament.

The Manchester United manager has predicted all group-stage scenarios ahead of next week's big kick-off and while he has been generous to the country he works in, he has been less charitable towards his native Portugal in Group B. Russia, according to Mourinho, will make it through.


MOURINHO'S MOSCOW MONEY

Jose Mourinho will earn £1.7m working FOUR DAYS for the Kremlin-backed TV channel RT (formerly Russia Today) during the World Cup. He will be their main pundit with the arrangement working out at more than £400,000 per day. The Manchester United manager will be in Moscow for four days at the start of the tournament and will then be on video link on the day of the final.  The deal was announced in March, a day after the Salisbury poisoning, and was criticised by MPs in the wake of the attack. In a statement, Rhondda MP Chris Bryant said: 'To my mind, this is blood money, paid directly from the Russian state coffers.' The channel was also attacked by politicians in France and the United States for pumping out propaganda in support of Russian president Vladimir Putin. There were also calls back in March for its UK broadcasting licence to be withdrawn. Mourinho said at the time: 'I am looking forward to attending the World Cup in Russia and sharing my insights.’

He  said: 'It is very difficult. I don't want to be emotional, but I have to be. I want my players to win, but I also want my players to go on holiday. So, this is going to be tough.'

But he exclaimed 'Come on England' as he tipped them to top their group ahead of main rivals Belgium.

As he backed Spain to top their group ahead of Portugal, he hinted at better fortunes ahead for the Euro 2016 champions: 'I will show later that I am totally Portuguese but they are going to finish second in the group.'

MOURINHO'S GROUP STAGE PREDICTIONS 

Group A: 1. Uruguay, 2. Russia, 3. Egypt, 4. Saudi Arabia

Group B: 1. Spain, 2. Portugal, 3. Morocco, 4. Iran

Group C: 1. France, 2. Australia, 3. Peru, 4. Denmark

Group D: 1. Argentina, 2. Nigeria, 3. Iceland, 4. Croatia

Group E: 1. Brazil, 2. Switzerland, 3. Serbia, 4. Costa Rica

Group F: 1. Germany, 2. Mexico, 3. Sweden, 4. South Korea

Group G: 1. England, 2. Belgium, 3. Panama, 4. Tunisia

Group H: 1. Senegal, 2. Poland, 3. Colombia, 4. Japan

In Group A he predicted an easy win for Uruguay, who he believes have 'experience, top players and the right mentality', and tipped hosts Russia to be too strong for Egypt.

France will have 'no problem' in topping Group C, but Mourinho pulled a surprise by claiming Australia will join them in the last 16.

Unsurprisingly he predicted Argentina and 'the little fella' would claim first place in Group D, but backed Nigeria to finish ahead of Iceland and Croatia.

In Group E he believes Brazil will come out on top, but had to apologise to Nemanja Matic for predicting an early exit for Serbia.

He said: 'I need Matic to go on a holiday, so Switzerland to finish second. I'm sorry Nemanja, but you need a holiday.'

Germany will top Group F ahead of Mexico, while in a 'quite balanced' Group H, Senegal will win ahead of Poland, according to the United boss.

Mourinho will be in Moscow throughout the tournament as a pundit for RT's World Cup coverage.

item.title: Alvaro Morata shares tender holiday snap with heavily pregnant wife Alice as he ponders future after Chelsea nightmare and World Cup snub
item.description: The picture, shared on Morata's Instagram account, shows the striker in a swimming pool with his wife, his hand tenderly on her belly. Campello is expecting twins, and looks as if she is due very soon.
item.content:encoded:
On the field, things are not going smoothly for Alvaro Morata - he was left out of Spain's 2018 World Cup squad after an underwhelming first season at Chelsea.

Off it, however, things look to be idyllic, as Morata shared a happy holiday photo with his heavily pregnant wife Alice Campello. 

The picture, shared on Morata's Instagram account, shows the striker in a swimming pool with his wife, his hand tenderly on her belly. Campello is expecting twins, and looks as if she is due to give birth very soon.


Morata captioned the picture: 'I wish everyone to find a love like ours! I cannot wait to meet our children.'

The image is also captioned with the hashtags 'Alessandro' and 'Leonardo', indicating the names of his two future sons have already been decided.

The snap is one of several loved-up photos of the couple posted by Morata and Campello in recent days. 

What remains undecided, however, is the team which Morata will be playing for next season, with his future uncertain after a disappointing year at Chelsea.

Morata's first season with the Blues plateaued towards the latter stages of the campaign after making a quick start to life in English football, and he has been linked with a move away.

AC Milan are among those interested in offering Morata a route out of Stamford Bridge this summer. 

Chelsea have also reportedly been offered the opportunity to buy Gonzalo Higuain as part of a plan by Juventus to bring Morata back to Serie A.

item.title: World Cup Golden Boot revealed in Moscow ahead of Russia 2018 where Lionel Messi and Neymar are joint favourites in battle for illustrious prize
item.description: Designed by adidas, the latest Golden Boot was unveiled in a pop-up store opened ahead of the tournament in Moscow's TsUM department store. It appears to be based on the adidas X 18+ boot.
item.content:encoded:
It is the prize that has been won by the likes of Ronaldo, Gary Lineker and Miroslav Klose over the years and now the 2018 incarnation of the World Cup Golden Boot has been revealed.

Designed by adidas, the latest Golden Boot was unveiled in a pop-up store in Moscow's TsUM department store ahead of the tournament's highly-anticipated kick-off.

Featuring the German sportswear giant's signature three stripes across the front, the award appears to be based on the adidas X 18+ boot.


There will be a number of the game's leading players eyeing up the prize that is presented to the top scorer at each World Cup finals. 

It was most recently won by Colombia's James Rodriguez after he scored six goals in Brazil four years ago.

Germany's Thomas Muller claimed the prize in South Africa in 2010 after he burst onto the international scene with five goals. 

PREVIOUS GOLDEN BOOT WINNERS

Uruguay 1930 - Guillermo Stabile, Argentina - 8 goals

Italy 1934 - Oldrich Nejedly, Czech Republic - 5 goals

France 1938 - Leonidas, Brazil - 7 goals

Brazil 1950 - Ademir, Brazil - 8 goals

Switzerland 1954 - Sandor Kocsis, Hungary - 11 goals

Sweden 1958 - Just Fontaine, France - 13 goals

Chile 1962 - Florian Albert, Hungary, Valentin Ivanov, Soviet Union, Garrincha, Brazil, Vava, Brazil, Drazan Jerkovic, Yugoslavia, Leonel Sanchez - 4 goals

England 1966 - Eusebio, Portugal - 9 goals

Mexico 1970 - Gerd Muller, Germany - 10 goals

West Germany 1974 - Grzegorz Lato, Poland - 7 goals 

Argentina 1978 - Mario Kempes, Argentina - 6 goals

Spain 1982 - Paolo Rossi, Italy - 6 goals

Mexico 1986 - Gary Lineker, England - 6 goals

Italy 1990 - Salvatore Schillaci, Italy - 6 goals

US 1994 - Oleg Salenko, Russia, Hristo Stoichkov, Bulgaria - 6 goals

France 1998 - Davor Suker, Croatia - 6 goals

South Korea / Japan 2002 - Ronaldo, Brazil - 8 goals

Germany 2006 - Miroslav Klose, Germany - 5 goals

South Africa 2010 - Thomas Muller, Germany - 5 goals

Brazil 2014 - James Rodriguez, Colombia - 6 goals 

WORLD CUP 2018 GOLDEN BOOT ODDS 

Lionel Messi - 10/1

Neymar - 10/1

Antoine Griezmann - 12/1

Gabriel Jesus - 14/1

Harry Kane - 14/1

Timo Werner - 14/1

Cristiano Ronaldo - 16/1

Romelu Lukaku 16/1 

Lionel Messi, Neymar, Antoine Griezmann, Gabriel Jesus and Harry Kane are the five leading contenders to claim the prize, according to bookmakers.

Messi will be hoping to finally win the World Cup title that has eluded him throughout his career while Neymar is keen to make amends for the disappointing way he ended the 2014 tournament on home soil with an injury.

Timo Werner, Cristiano Ronaldo, Romelu Lukaku, Diego Costa and Luis Suarez are also expected to be in the hunt.

The World Cup officially gets under way on June 14 when hosts Russia take on Saudi Arabia at the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow.

item.title: 'City were being punished by Financial Fair Play... it was impossible': Manuel Pellegrini reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez or Arturo Vidal at Manchester City due to FFP rules
item.description: Manuel Pellegrini has opened up about the struggles he faced as Manchester City boss and reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez or Arturo Vidal due to Financial Fair Play rules.
item.content:encoded:
Manuel Pellegrini has opened up about the struggles he faced while in charge of Manchester City and reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez and Arturo Vidal due to Financial Fair Play punishments. 

Pellegrini won the Premier League with City in 2013-14 but admits he was unable to bring in all the players he wanted due to the impact of FFP regulations.

'I tried to bring them in but City were being punished by Financial Fair Play - it was impossible,' he explained.  


The 64-year-old Chilean is the new boss of West Ham but in an interview with outlet El Mercurio, Pellegrini opens up on life at Real Madrid, his relationship with Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho and the player that was the most complicated to manage. 

And it is life at Madrid that will be the most eye-opening for football fans - especially as Los Blancos continue their search to replace Zinedine Zidane following his resignation.

Pellegrini was at the Bernabeu for one season and despite having a 75 per cent win percentage, was shown the door in favour of Mourinho.

'One of the most frequent discussions that I had with the Real Madrid directors was about the players' performance,' he continued.

'They told me some players had to play no matter what, but I never compromised.' 

The Chilean coached some of the finest talents in world football during that season with both Cristiano Ronaldo and Raul at his attacking disposal. 

But while he reveals decisions were made for him in the Spanish capital, he reserves special praise for the two Madrid forwards.  

'During my career the easiest players to direct have been Cristiano and Raul,' he said. 

'It doesn't matter how much they win, they are excellent sportsmen.'

item.title: John Stones hopes Vincent Kompany returns from injury for Belgium at the World Cup... and faces England
item.description: Kompany's injury curse struck again when he hurt his groin during a pre-tournament friendly against Portugal. The fragile 32-year-old was forced out of Euro 2016 on fitness grounds.
item.content:encoded:
John Stones is willing Manchester City team-mate Vincent Kompany back to fitness for the World Cup, even though that would strengthen England's Group G rivals Belgium.

Kompany's injury curse struck again over the weekend when he hurt his groin during a pre-tournament friendly against Portugal.

The fragile 32-year-old was forced out of Euro 2016 on fitness grounds and has been left sweating over his spot in Russia following his latest setback.


Belgium boss Roberto Martinez has named Kompany in his 23-man squad but Laurent Ciman is standing by to replace him if he does not make it.

A fully fit Kompany would be a huge asset, and potentially a thorn in England's side, but Stones is pulling for the City captain.

'I hope Vinny gets back as soon as possible, his health is the main thing,' he said. 'He's a great player and a great leader and it's sad to hear he's got a little injury. I don't know the extent of it but I'd definitely love to see him - and anyone from City - at the World Cup.

'I never want anyone to get injured. It's a blow for Belgium, for City and for me because I'm his friend. He's got to get back and I hope he does as soon as possible. It's sad news to hear but he has been named (in the squad) so fingers crossed for Vinny.'

Stones suffered his own share of injury problems in the second half of City's Premier League title-winning season.

He missed games with knee and abductor issues, as well as suffering a concussion with England in March, contributing to his peripheral part in City's triumphant run-in, and while that was a frustration, at least there is no prospect of the 24-year-old complaining of excess fatigue once the tournament begins.

'I'm definitely not burned out,' he said ahead of Thursday's final friendly against Costa Rica in Leeds. 'I'm excited about my football, I want to be out in training or playing if there's a game.

'People don't realise when you're injured you're working twice as hard but I'm not mentally burned out or anything. I'm excited to get going.

'This is my first World Cup, it's a massive honour for me and I definitely want to try and enjoy every second on and off the pitch.'

item.title: Mexico national team 'partied for 24 hours with 30 escorts' at private party just two weeks before the World Cup
item.description: Mexico's national team is facing fresh controversy over claims several footballers partied with prostitutes after a friendly against Scotland less than two weeks before their first World Cup match.
item.content:encoded:
Mexico's national team was facing fresh controversy on Wednesday over claims several footballers partied with prostitutes after a friendly against Scotland less than two weeks before their first World Cup match.

Eight members of Mexico's Copa America squad were dropped in 2011 over allegations they were visited by escorts in a team hotel.

Several players have been implicated in new claims involving hookers by Mexican media.

Mexican magazine TV Notas said the bad behaviour occurred when the footballers were given the night off after Saturday's 1-0 home win against Scotland thanks to an early goal by former Spurs striker Giovanni dos Santos.

The magazine, referring to the Mexican squad by their nickname El Tri, claimed the stars celebrated with a no-holds-barred party lasting more than a day in a report titled: 'Thirty VIP escorts gave the TRI their real World Cup send-off with a 24-hour lock-in.'

It said the party had taken place at a house in an upmarket neighbourhood in Mexico City called Las Lomas de Chapultepec which started after Saturday's match against Scotland at the Azteca Stadium and went on till 4pm on Sunday.


The magazine, whose report was widely echoed by Mexican and south American media, quoted a source as saying: 'They arrived at the house in Las Lomas around 10.30pm on Saturday and had a great time with music, drinks, games and women. They had the night off, without their wives and girlfriends.'

The unidentified insider, asked why their partners had not been at the party, told TV Notas: 'Because they wanted to be a bit naughty. Why else would they have needed 30 escorts!'

The magazine said its source had told them the players at the party included goalie Guillermo Ochoa, defender Carlos Salcedo, midfielder Marco Fabian, and former Spurs player Giovanni dos Santos who is currently with LA Galaxy, as well as his brother Jonathan.

Mexico are due to play Denmark in a last friendly on Saturday before jetting to Russia where they meet Germany in their first World Cup game on June 17. El Tri have made it out of the group stage in every World Cup it has participated in since 1986.

Jonathan dos Santos apologised after becoming one of eight players dropped from Mexico's Copa America squad in 2011 following his involvement in that year's prostitution scandal.

He said after it was discovered hookers had been invited into the team's pre-cup base in Ecuador capital Quito: 'I'm here to face the music. I have committed misconduct. I am very sorry for what I did and I apologize to the team, my teammates, the entire coaching staff and people of Mexico. I'm here and I assume responsibility.'

The young midfielder, who was at Barcelona at the time, added: 'I have to apologize to my club, and to my family. I have a very clean record - nine years at the club and there has never been any problem with me.'

Local reports at the time said the players had been fined and suspended from national duty for six months.

Scotland manager Alex McLeish described his team's match against Mexico at the weekend as an 'amazing experience' and said he was 'proud of every single one of the players.' There is no suggestion any of his squad were at the party.

Overnight the Mexican Football Federation FEMEXFUT made its first official comments and appeared to indicate no disciplinary action would be taken over the party.

FEMEXFUT Secretary General Guillermo Cantu, asked if there would be any punishment for the players who appear in the photos published by TV Notas, told reporters: 'These are the risks freedom has and we're not going to change that.'

He added: 'A day off is a day off. They're the risks you have with freedom. It's not whether we like it or not. We're just got to be clear that it's a day off and they haven't missed training or a team get-together.

'The issue of values is a separate matter. I'm not going to condemn the players. The issue of freedom is a complex one of course but it's a personal, free decision as to how they spend their free time.'

Social media users expressed outrage over his comments. One football fan wrote: 'The girlfriends and wives will make sure they're punished.'

item.title: 'He was a magic horse': 2008 Gold Cup winner Denman dies aged 18 as trainer Paul Nicholls says he was 'put to sleep painlessly'
item.description: Denman claimed four Grade One races and was also twice successful in the Hennessy Gold Cup at Newbury in 2007 and 2009. He retired in 2011 and earned over £1million in prize-money.
item.content:encoded:
Denman, the 2008 Cheltenham Gold Cup winner, died on Tuesday at the age of 18, trainer Paul Nicholls told Betfair.

Nicholls said the brilliant chaser 'had begun to go downhill in the past few days', and was 'put to sleep painlessly'.

The Ditcheat handler said: 'The decision was taken by his devoted owner Paul Barber with the full support of myself, our head lad Clifford Baker and our vet Buffy Shirley-Beavan.


'We all agreed it was the right thing to do because but he had begun to go downhill in the past few days and we did not want to see him suffer.'

Denman was renowned for his iron will on a racecourse and won 14 races from 24 starts.

His finest hour came in the 2008 Cheltenham Gold Cup, when he defeated stablemate Kauto Star by seven lengths in a race for the ages.

Denman claimed four Grade One races and was also twice successful in the Hennessy Gold Cup at Newbury in 2007 and 2009. He retired in 2011 and earned over £1million in prize-money.

Nicholls said: 'Denman was known affectionately to punters and racegoers as "The Tank", which I always felt was a fitting description.

'He was a magic horse who had a tremendous following because of the wholehearted way he went about his racing.

'He was tough, hardy and willing, wasn't the easiest to train, and would bite your hand off in his box given half a chance.

'He came along at the right time and was one of our superstars during a golden era for Team Ditcheat.'

DENMAN'S 14 WINS

October 23, 2005: 2m5½f Vixen Horsefeeds Novices' Hurdle Class E (Wincanton)

November 17, 2005: 2m5½f Hamilton Litestat Novices' Hurdle Class D (Wincanton)

item.title: Brazil players - including Manchester United new boy Fred - get pre-World Cup haircuts from London barber
item.description: As they prepare for the World Cup in order to look sharp on the pitch, the Brazil players are also aiming to look sharp off it too. The five-time world champions are training in London.
item.content:encoded:
As they prepare for the World Cup in order to look sharp on the pitch, the Brazil players are also aiming to look sharp off it too.

The five-time world champions are training in London at Tottenham's Enfield facility, and played a friendly against Croatia at Anfield on Sunday. 

While in Liverpool, several Brazilian stars got themselves a haircut, including Chelsea midfielder Willian and Manchester City pair Ederson and Gabriel Jesus. 

Scroll down for video. 


Midfielder Fred also got his black barnet newly coiffured and shaped, with a special gel added that made his spiky curls glitter.

HD Cutz, normally based in Battersea, London, sent a barber up to the Brazilians' hotel in Liverpool and the firm posted several clips and pictures of the players after their haircuts.

The video of Fred was captioned: 'You future is bright brother' - and it turned out to be prescient of events a couple of days later.

On Tuesday, it was confirmed Fred will be back in the north-west of England next season and has joined Manchester United in a £52million deal.

HD Cutz has gained a reputation for being the chosen stylist of many footballers, proudly counting Raheem Sterling and Leon Bailey among clients on its website, as well as being the Belgium team barber from 2015 to 2018.

The company can now count Brazil among its customers, with the Samba Boys carrying that style onto the pitch as they beat Croatia 2-0 on Sunday.

Neymar and Roberto Firmino got the goals as Brazil continued their preparations for Russia with a victory.

item.title: 'Let's go for some runs': Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang posts selfie with £250,000 Aston Martin before keeping up his fitness
item.description: The Gabon striker, who scored 10 goals for the Gunners last campaign, will not feature at the World Cup. Aubameyang posted a selfie with a blue Aston Martin on to his Instagram story.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal striker Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang has been keeping up his fitness following the end of the season.

The Gabon striker, who scored 10 goals for the Gunners last campaign, will not feature at the World Cup.

Aubameyang posted a selfie with a £250,000 blue Aston Martin on to his Instagram story on Tuesday morning. 

Alongside the snap he wrote: 'Let's go for some runs,' in a Nike tracksuit top.

It is not clear where Aubameyang was for his training session, but the German number plate on his supercar suggests he may have returned to Dortmund. 

Gabon finished third in their World Cup qualifying group last November, which was won by Morocco.

Aubameyang has a new team-mate at the Emirates after the club confirmed the signing of veteran full back Stephan Lichtsteiner on a free transfer from Juventus on Tuesday.


The Switzerland international becomes the first Gunners signing confirmed since Unai Emery succeeded Arsene Wenger as manager.

Emery told the club website: 'Stephan brings huge experience and leadership to our squad. He's a player with great quality with a very positive and determined attitude. Stephan will improve us on and off the pitch.'

item.title: Spain goalkeeper David de Gea snubs country's new Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez in act of 'revenge' after leader criticised Man United keeper when he was implicated in sex assault claims two years ago
item.description: This is the extraordinary moment Manchester United's goalkeeper keeps his hands in his pockets as his Spain teammates applaud his country's new PM in a 'snub' dubbed 'De Gea's revenge.'
item.content:encoded:
This is the extraordinary moment Manchester United's goalkeeper keeps his hands in his pockets as his Spain teammates applaud his country's new PM in a 'snub' dubbed 'De Gea's revenge.'

Socialist leader Pedro Sanchez criticised the shot-stopper two years ago when he was implicated in sex assault claims David de Gea always denied any involvement in.

Sanchez said in an interview at the time: 'I don't feel comfortable with De Gea as the national team's goalkeeper.' 


Footage taken of his visit on Tuesday to Las Rozas, the Spain squad's pre-World Cup base in Madrid, showed his team-mates applauding the politician while De Gea stared ahead with a serious look on his face and his hands deep in his pockets.

Sanchez, who recently replaced Mariano Rajoy as Spain's new PM after winning a no-confidence motion he proposed, had just wished the footballers good luck and urged them to return from Russia as winners in a short address. 

De Gea appeared to be the only one of the players present who failed to applaud his country's new PM.

He was seen shaking Sanchez's hand before the politician's speech, although with a stern look on his face which contrasted with the smiles of his team-mates. 

And he kept his hands in his pockets and stayed on the edge of the group as the the socialist leader posed for pictures with the squad with a Spain football top bearing his name. 

President Sanchez sought out De Gea afterwards and apologised to the goalkeeper for his comments and recognised the hurt caused.  

The allegations against the Manchester United player, denied from the start by De Gea, were later said to be false. De Gea accepted the politician's apology and the two men left on good terms.  

Spanish media were quick to claim De Gea had deliberately snubbed Sanchez.

El Espanol wrote: 'De Gea ignores and doesn't applaud Pedro Sanchez two years after he 'accused' him of child abuse.'

Marca said: 'David de Gea was cold and distant with the Spanish PM.'

Another well-read Spanish news website branded the incident: 'David de Gea's revenge against Pedro Sanchez.'

The Manchester United player was linked in 2016 to an under-age prostitution ring allegedly involving a Spanish porn director.

An unnamed prostitute accused him of organising a sex party with the porn director at a five-star Madrid hotel in 2012 where she says two footballers physically and sexually abused her and another woman.

Reports at the time said she also claimed the goalkeeper subsequently tried to set up an orgy with him and United teammates.

De Gea took time out of his Euro 2016 preparation to brand the reports as lies.

De Gea said at the time: 'I want to refute these allegations. These are lies and mistruths. The matter remains in the hands of my lawyers. It is all false.' 

His girlfriend Edurne Garcia also stood by him throughout.

It later emerged the woman's allegations were false and De Gea and another well-known Spanish player she tried to implicate - were not called to give evidence by an investigating judge.

As well as admitting he did not feel comfortable with De Gea in goal for Spain, Sanchez also said at the time: 'I respect the presumption of innocence but above all, you have to put yourself in the shoes of the victim.'

De Gea and Sanchez appeared to have put a lid on their difference of opinion on Wednesday.

De Gea was quoted as admitting after the tense moment: 'I think there was a time when I wasn't treated as I should have been.

'Many people criticised me knowing that what had been said wasn't right.'

Luis Rubiales, the president of the Spanish Football Federation, told a Spanish radio station: 'The mess with De Gea has resolved itself.

'Pedro Sanchez has been friendly and affectionate, he has spoken with him and he has told him he's happy everything turned out okay. He has shown humility.'

item.title: 'I always believe players play much better at home': LeBron James expects Cleveland Cavaliers to step up in game three of the NBA finals
item.description: James was sensational in the two losses to Golden State on the road in Oakland but despite scoring 51 points in game one, he has mostly been a one-man army against the Warriors.
item.content:encoded:
Cleveland Cavaliers forward LeBron James expects his team-mates to step up their game when the NBA Finals shift to the Quicken Loans Arena on Wednesday (2am Thursday BST), a boost his team will need to avoid falling into a 3-0 hole in the best-of-seven series.

James was sensational in the two losses to Golden State on the road in Oakland but despite scoring 51 points in game one and having a near triple double in game two, he has mostly been a one-man army against the deep and talented Warriors squad.

'I always believe the role players play much better at home than they do on the road,' James told reporters in Cleveland on Tuesday.

'They feed off the crowd. They feed off the familiarity with not only being home but being on their home floor, having their own locker and things of that nature.

'So I think that's definitely helped us out a lot throughout this post-season thus far. Pretty much in the post-season since I returned a few years ago.'

James has good reason to think the Cavs will be a better when the ball goes up on their home court, where they have only dropped one game this post-season and have at times looked like an entirely different team.


In the Eastern Conference Finals the Cavs won all three of their home games against the Boston Celtics by comfortable margins but were blown out in three of the four games they played at TD Garden.

The Cavaliers stole game seven of that series on the road to advance to the finals, where they are battling the defending champion Warriors for the fourth consecutive year.

While seemingly playing the Warriors by himself in game one, James saw better production from Kevin Love (22 points) and George Hill (15 points) in game two, an upward trend he will hope continues.

Cavaliers coach Tyronn Lue said the team understands the series will be a short one if they cannot win in Cleveland.

'We've got to take care of home,' he said. 'I think we've done a great job of playing here throughout the course of the play-offs. Our fans are great. They're going to be ready and fired up.

'(The Warriors) took care of their home court. They won two games on their home floor. Now we've got to come back and do the same thing.'

Game four is also in Cleveland on Friday.

item.title: Egypt hopeful Mohamed Salah will be fit enough to play full part in World Cup but coach Hector Cuper admits they 'cannot depend on him'
item.description: Egypt are hopeful Mohamed Salah will be available for the start of their World Cup campaign in Russia but the team must find a way to avoid depending too much on the striker.
item.content:encoded:
Egypt are hopeful Mohamed Salah will be available for the start of their World Cup campaign in Russia but they must find a way to avoid depending too much on him, coach Hector Cuper has said.

Liverpool's Salah is recovering from the shoulder ligament injury suffered in last month's Champions League final loss to Real Madrid when he went off early in the game.

'We hope we won't be affected, we try to be the same team, we can't be dependent on one player,' Cuper was quoted as saying by Sky Sports.


'He's important but if he's not fit in time we will be ready with another player.

'This is football, these things can happen to any player. We could need to substitute him, but we hope that won't be the case.'

Salah was included in Egypt's final 23-man squad, with the team's medical staff suggesting it will be touch and go for the player to be ready in time for their Group A game against Uruguay in Ekaterinburg on June 15.

'Salah is in a stage of recovery not just for treatment on his shoulder,' Cuper added. 'We need to improve his demeanour and his fitness level because the injury has prevented him from training as a normal player.

'But we have very good news from our doctor, we hope he will be with us before Uruguay. We are optimists and we are waiting for him.'

Salah, who netted 44 goals in an incredible first season for Liverpool after joining from AS Roma, was voted Player of the Year by the Football Writers' Association last month, becoming the first African to win the prestigious award.

item.title: Raphael Varane says Zinedine Zidane's successor as Real Madrid manager has huge shoes to fill: 'He has done something that will be difficult to follow... it was extraordinary'
item.description: Real Madrid's new coach will have to 'adapt to Real Madrid' in order to successfully replace Zinedine Zidane, according to defender Raphael Varane.
item.content:encoded:
Zinedine Zidane's replacement will have to 'adapt to Real Madrid' in order to successfully replace the legendary Frenchman, according to defender Raphael Varane.

Zidane shocked the football world by stepping down as Real manager just days after leading them to a third successive Champions League triumph.

He won nine trophies in total during his two-and-a-half-year spell at the Bernabeu and Varane knows it will require a strong character to replace him.


Juventus boss Massimiliano Allegri, Tottenham's Mauricio Pochettino, outgoing Chelsea manager Antonio Conte and former Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger are among the names in the frame.

'The new coach must be able to evolve in the Madrid context because it's not easy, it's a context with a lot of pressure and expectations,' Varane said.

'Zidane has done something that will be difficult to do again. What he has done in two and a half years is extraordinary.

'We're not going to ask the new coach to win so many trophies in such a short time, but he will have to adapt to Real Madrid.

'There are very good coaches in Europe - the new coach will have to have the character to take up this challenge.'

Zidane's final match in charge saw Real defeat Liverpool 3-1 in Kiev to become the first team to complete a hat-trick of Champions League titles.

They defeated Atletico Madrid on penalties to win the 2016 final and stuffed Juventus 4-1 last year.

Varane, who played 44 times for Real last season, now heads to the World Cup with France, where they have been drawn with Peru, Australia and Denmark in Group C.

item.title: Man United defender Marcos Rojo says Argentina are motivated by desire to make amends for 2014 World Cup disappointment as they head to Russia
item.description: Argentina players will do everything in their power in Russia to help the team lift the World Cup trophy again after falling at the last hurdle four years ago in Brazil, defender Marcos Rojo has said.
item.content:encoded:
Argentina players will do everything in their power in Russia to help the team lift the World Cup trophy again after falling at the last hurdle four years ago in Brazil, defender Marcos Rojo has said.

The 28-year-old Manchester United centre-back, capped 56 times by Argentina, and his team-mates suffered a last-gasp 1-0 defeat by Germany in the 2014 final.

'It's a really important thing and a big deal for any Argentinian to wear that shirt,' Rojo told United's official website. 'We really feel the shirt a lot and we defend our colours.


'We give everything when we are wearing it and we want payback for the way things happened at the last World Cup.

'We will do everything to give our fans the possibility to celebrate winning the trophy again.'

Rojo will face Nigeria in the World Cup group stage, a team he scored his first international goal against in the 2014 World Cup.

Croatia and Iceland are their other two opponents in Group D and Rojo feels Argentina's progress in the tournament would depend on Lionel Messi's goalscoring abilities.

'It's Nigeria again!' he said. 'I think it's three or four times now we've been drawn with Nigeria and it will be a difficult group. Croatia and Iceland are in there too.

'Hopefully, Lionel Messi will be in form and can do something for us.'

Argentina have cancelled their final World Cup warm-up match against Israel, as the political pressure grew ahead of Saturday's scheduled fixture in Jerusalem.

They will kick off their World Cup campaign in Russia against Iceland on June 16.

item.title: 'The togetherness is going to pull us through': Kyle Walker believes squad unity will carry England far in the World Cup
item.description: The unity within the England squad will help the players flourish at the World Cup, defender Kyle Walker has said ahead of the team's final warm-up match against Costa Rica on Thursday.
item.content:encoded:
The unity within the England squad will help the players flourish at the World Cup, defender Kyle Walker has said ahead of the team's final warm-up match against Costa Rica on Thursday.

England are aiming to move past underwhelming campaigns at the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 European Championship by progressing deep in Russia and Walker feels the harmony within the squad will aid their cause.

'I fully believe in the players that we have in the squad. The manager has brought some brilliant ideas and we've all bought into it,' the Manchester City full-back said.

'Now that we all click, I feel quite comfortable sitting with anyone and talking to them.


'That's the environment that we need to take into the World Cup because the quality in the team is going to show for itself but also the togetherness is going to pull us through.'

City playmaker Raheem Sterling agreed.

'Everyone here gets along no matter what club you're from,' Sterling said.

'Once we get here we're always together, always having a laugh and a joke, so it's great to see.'

England open their World Cup campaign against Group G rivals Tunisia on June 18. Panama and Belgium are the other teams in the group.

item.title: Argentina cancel final World Cup warm-up friendly against Israel in Jerusalem after widespread protests
item.description: The match at Jerusalem's Teddy Stadium was to be Argentina's last before they kick off their World Cup campaign in Russia on June 16 when they face Iceland at the Spartak Stadium in Moscow.
item.content:encoded:
Argentina have cancelled their final World Cup warm-up match against Israel, striker Gonzalo Higuain said on Tuesday, as political pressure grew ahead of Saturday's scheduled fixture in Jerusalem.

'They've finally done the right thing,' Higuain told ESPN, confirming reports the game had been cancelled.

The match at Jerusalem's Teddy Stadium was to be Argentina's last before they kick off their World Cup campaign in Russia on June 16.


ARGENTINA FIXTURES 

GROUP D 

June 16 - Argentina vs Iceland - 2pm BST, Spartak Stadium, Moscow

June 21 - Argentina vs Croatia - 7pm BST, Nizhny Novgorod Stadium

June 26 - Argentina vs Nigeria - 7pm BST, Saint Petersburg Stadium

There was no initial reaction from the Israeli FA or from Israeli politicians. Reports said that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called Argentinian President Mauricio Macri to ask him to persuade the team not to cancel their visit.

Israel Radio quoted an unnamed diplomatic official who said the chances of salvaging the fixture were very slim.

The visit of Argentina has attracted huge interest among Israeli fans, mainly due to anticipation surrounding Lionel Messi's presence in Jerusalem.

Palestinians celebrated the cancellation. In Gaza, people cheered and in Ramallah in the West Bank, the Palestinian FA issued a statement reading: 'We thank Argentina's players led by star Messi for refusing to be used to serve a non-sporting goal.'

Palestinian FA chairman Jibril Rajoub said: 'Values, morals and sport have secured a victory today and a red card was raised at Israel through the cancellation of the game.'

Rajoub called a news conference for Wednesday in Ramallah, which he will hold outside the Argentinian representative's office. On Sunday, he called for Palestinians to burn replica shirts and pictures of Messi.

The stadium that was to host the match is in west Jerusalem. The Palestinians want the eastern part of the city as the capital of a future state that will include the Gaza Strip and the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

However, the status of Jerusalem is highly sensitive. The match was originally slated to be played in Haifa but Israeli authorities contributed funding for it to be moved to Jerusalem, irking Palestinians further following US President Donald Trump's recognition of the city as Israel's capital. The US embassy was moved there last month.

The cancellation is just one more obstacle for Argentina, who were beaten finalists at the World Cup in Brazil four years ago and whose preparations have been troubled this time around.

They suffered a heavy defeat to Spain in a friendly and lost their first-choice goalkeeper Sergio Romero to injury, giving little encouragement to fans who watched the team struggle to qualify for the tournament in Russia.

The two-time World Cup winners face Iceland, Nigeria and Croatia in what is considered to be one of the hardest groups in the tournament.

item.title: Everton's Director of Football Marcel Brands admits high wage bill means selling players could prove problematic: 'A lot of their salaries mean they cannot play anywhere'
item.description: Director of Football Marcel Brands has admitted Everton must sell before they can spend heavily this summer window as he clears up the expensive mistakes of the club's previous failed regime.
item.content:encoded:
Marcel Brands has admitted Everton must sell before they can spend heavily this summer as he clears up the expensive mistakes of the club's previous failed regime.

Brands has arrived from PSV Eindhoven to take over from Steve Walsh as Director of Football; Walsh was sacked from his £1million-per-year role last month having overseen a disastrous recruitment drive that saw Everton spend £239million on transfer fees over a 12 month period.

Marco Silva, the new manager, has inherited a squad with 38 players. Many have seen their values depreciate and are on lucrative contracts - Everton's wage bill is close to 80 per cent of their turnover - and Brands is conscious that moving people on will be difficult.


There will be a number of meetings with players and agents in the coming weeks and a significant number will move on, headed by those who no longer wish to be on Merseyside - Morgan Schneiderlin, who attracted interest from West Ham in January, is one name on that list.

When asked if Everton needed to sell to buy, Brands replied: 'Yes - but it's not only a money thing. Of course money is also important, but it is also for a coach it is not workable to start with 38 players in your squad.

'A lot of them are not young players any more. We have to be honest when we take the decision with these players, do they have prospects here at Everton? Some of conversations will not be nice, but it has to be honest, and I think Marco must start with a squad that everyone is eager to play.

'I know it's hard. You have to be careful because if you make a new signing - because of the salaries in England - then it's difficult if the player is not successful then what do you do? In most countries they cannot make the wages they get here in the Premier League.

'So a lot of players who don't play (at Everton) cannot play anywhere, as the salaries are not comparable. 

'That means even if you have money you have to be careful to spend that money. I always say when you buy 10 players eight or nine have to do well.' 

The predicament Brands is bracing himself for is those who are on huge contracts insisting they will stay where they are. It gives an indication of just how excessive the policy was last summer when nine players arrived.

'Hopefully I will succeed to offload the right players,' said Brands. 'And, of course, they are good players so I hope there will be interest for a few of our players. 

'There will be meetings with the players and with the agents, yes. We need to offload players to raise money (to spend).'

item.title: Waitress files $1m lawsuit against Formula One driver Kimi Raikkonen over accusations of sexual misconduct
item.description: JONATHAN MCEVOY: Kimi Raikkonen flies into a legal storm in Montreal on Wednesday after a waitress filed a $1million lawsuit against him over accusations of sexual misconduct.
item.content:encoded:
Kimi Raikkonen flies into a legal storm in Montreal on Wednesday after a waitress filed a $1million lawsuit against him over accusations of sexual misconduct following the Canadian Grand Prix two years ago.

The waitress claims the 2007 Formula One world champion touched her breasts while he was drunk in a bar.

The woman first made allegations online in 2016, though she did not name the Ferrari man at the time. Earlier this year, the waitress posted a follow-up story saying she had protected the driver for long enough and, in April, she gave her side of the story to police.

Raikkonen, 38, denies the claims and alleges he is the victim of blackmail. His lawyers, who have lodged an extortion counterclaim, said: ‘Our client makes it clear that everything this woman does is illegal.’ 

But Jamie Benizri, founder of Legal Logik, the firm representing the accuser, told Autosport: ‘It is not a question of cashing out and running to the bank. It is a question of trying to understand what happened in 2016.’ 

He said Raikkonen’s complaint was ‘like trying to kill an ant with a bazooka’.

Ferrari president Sergio Marchionne said: ‘We investigated the case internally and know that Kimi is not involved. We stand behind him and are ready to defend him at all costs.’
