item.title: Leicester boss Claude Puel continues to push for West Brom defender Jonny Evans despite sizeable agent's fee
item.description: Leicester City manager Claude Puel is continuing to push for West Brom defender Jonny Evans. The 30-year-old has a £3million buyout clause though his representatives want a sizeable fee.
item.content:encoded:
Leicester City manager Claude Puel is continuing to push for West Brom defender Jonny Evans.

The 30-year-old has a £3million buyout clause though his representatives want a sizeable commission.

A £4m agent’s fee set by Evans' representative Colin Murdock is causing serious discussions at the King Power Stadium as it is greater than the transfer cost.


Leicester also hope to complete a deal for Patrick Roberts from Manchester City and have lodged enquiries for Andros Townsend at Crystal Palace.

Roberts has spent the last two seasons developing on loan with Scottish champions Celtic, but despite some impressive displays he is still a long way away from becoming a first-team regular at Manchester City. 

They also remain among the front runners for Norwich City midfielder James Maddison, as Sportsmail reported in April.

The Foxes have also enquired after Aston Villa's Jack Grealish plus Trabzonspor's teenage winger Abdulkadir Omur.

item.title: 'I see myself playing in one of the great clubs... like Manchester United': Levante's rising star Emmanuel Boateng dreams of Old Trafford switch
item.description: Levante's promising young striker, Emmanuel Boateng, has put himself on Jose Mourinho's radar after revealing he is dreaming of a move to a 'big club like Manchester United'.
item.content:encoded:
Levante's promising young striker, Emmanuel Boateng, has put himself on Jose Mourinho's radar after revealing he is dreaming of a move to a 'big club like Manchester United'. 

The 22-year-old announced himself on the world stage last month with a hat-trick against Barcelona in Levante's 5-4 win. It ended Barcelona's unbeaten run at the very end of the league campaign.

Now Boateng is ready for his next challenge and has claimed he see's himself playing for one of the biggest clubs in the world. 


‘I always dream big, I see myself playing in one of the great clubs of the world in the next five years,’ said Boateng. 

‘Big clubs like Manchester United and Barcelona excite me.’ 

The Ghanian made his international debut against Japan in a friendly last week and scored in the 2-0 win.

Manchester United are reportedly interested in bolstering their attacking options this window and with a view to bringing in someone as a back-up for Romelu Lukaku, Boateng could be an option.

United have already completed one signing this summer, bringing in Brazilian Fred in a deal worth £52m.

Boateng has not been prolific in front of goal so far in his career but continues to impress. 

He has moved from club to club, having started his professional career at Rio Ave in Portugal. 

After one season with the first-team squad he was picked up by Moreirense where he spent two years before moving across the border to La Liga.

Boateng also scored the opener in Levante's 2-2 draw with Real Madrid back in February.

Mourinho will be looking at a number of attacking options and United have also been linked with swoops for Gareth Bale and Marko Arnautovic among others.

item.title: The story behind Oldham Athletic's financial troubles... from mystifying transfers, unpaid wages and dressing room rows to fears the club may be football's next Leyton Orient
item.description: MIKE KEEGAN - SPECIAL REPORT: A staggering tale of wasted investment and belief-defying decision-making has resulted in concerns that Oldham may become the next Leyton Orient.
item.content:encoded:
When Rochdale's Joe Thompson capped his second recovery from cancer by scoring the goal which kept his side in League One it completed a fitting end to an emotional story. It also meant that neighbours Oldham Athletic, founder members of the Premier League, completed their 24-year slide from top division to bottom. 

What follows is a staggering tale of wasted investment and belief-defying decision-making that has resulted in serious concerns that the Lancashire club may become football's next Leyton Orient. 

In late-January, Oldham announced that they had been taken over by Dubai-based Moroccan Abdallah Lemsagam, a former agent. The reality was that Lemsagam had actually been providing the funds to keep the club operating since the start of their 21st consecutive season in League One. His arrival coincided with an influx of foreign players, predominantly French-speaking, at his recommendation. 


Many were signed on wages previously well outside Oldham's budget. Midfielder Mohamed Maouche was given £4,000-a-week. He subsequently played 10 minutes of League One football (and remains on the payroll). The biggest name, however, was a Dutch Under 21 winger Queensy Menig, who joined on loan from French club Nantes. 

It can be disclosed that Menig was paid a mind-boggling sum of around £11,650-a-week, plus accommodation at Manchester's swanky Malmaison hotel. 'I wanted to give the fans a present, to make them dream,' Lemsagam told Sportsmail. 

Whilst the intention would appear to be admirable, the reality was that Menig caused more problems than he solved and departed following four starts and one goal. 

Insiders say the experiment in total cost around £500,000. The wastage continued. Deals for three key loan players had to be renegotiated in January. The weekly bill for the three, one of whom signed permanently, went from £3,750 to around £16,000. As a result of actions like the above, Oldham's wage budget abruptly spiralled from around £1.4m to a frightening figure approaching £2.4m.  

The scattergun recruitment did not have the desired effect on the pitch and tempers frayed. In mid-April, Oldham were leading Gillingham 1-0 and looked like picking up an incredibly important three points. They did not know it at the time, but victory would have kept them up. In injury-time Wilfried Moimbe, another new arrival from France, reacted to a foul in the area by throwing a punch. He was sent off, the visitors scored the resulting penalty and three points became one.

At half-time during a vital home match with Southend United, and with Oldham losing 1-0, Lemsagam entered the dressing room. He says it was to support his players. Others say he left after looking around the room without saying a word. Regardless, one senior player visited the owner to plead with him not to do it again. Oldham lost 3-0. 

At a training session at Brentford, before another key away match at Wimbledon, one player reacted with audible dismay when informed that he would not be starting. Later, he was told to come to the front of the room at the hotel in which the team were staying, and apologise to his team mates. 'It was disastrous for morale,' said one onlooker. 

On another occasion, a striker denied a lucrative January move to a club closer to his home, almost came to blows with the new owner. His form subsequently dipped dramatically and Oldham are now keen to sell him. 

And then there is the case of Ousmane Fane. Fane, an energetic midfielder signed from Kidderminster in 2016, was called to see the chairman following 'disciplinary issues' and told to stay away from the club with two games left to save the season. Lemsagam claims this move was made with the backing of manager Richie Wellens, who told him that he did not need the player. 

Fane had previously played in 46 games. Without him, Oldham could only muster two draws and their departure from a division they had occupied since 1997 was confirmed with Thompson's goal.

Amid this backdrop comes more serious issues. Wages have not been paid on time for the last six months. On one occasion, a player claimed he could not turn up for training because he had no money to put petrol in his car. A member of office staff is understood to have taken out a credit card before Christmas to enable them to buy presents. Some members of staff have still not picked up their salaries from April. 

On Thursday, the latest payday, a handful of office staff and no players or playing staff received their wages. On Monday that remained the case. A number of agents have told Sportsmail they will no longer allow their players to sign for Oldham because there is no confidence that they will be paid. 

Three members of staff have departed and are considering taking the club to an employment tribunal. And the bills pile up. A fortnight ago club members of staff spent around a week unable to use their mobile phones because O2's account had not been settled. A dispute with a company brought in to look after the pitch is heading for court. 

Payments for tickets sold for away matches last season have not been paid to a number of clubs including local rivals Bury and Rochdale. Contributors to the programme have not received their relatively-tiny amounts since December. And then there is the big one. A bill of around £130,000 to HMRC has gone unpaid. 

There are fears winding-up proceedings may not be far away and insiders have genuine concerns that the end could well be nigh for the 123-year-old club. Lemsagam, externally at least, remains calm. He says that he is 'cleaning up' a vast array of issues inherited from the previous regime led by former owner Simon Corney, who declined to comment for this piece. He may well have a point and there has to be some sympathy, but increasing the wage bill by £1m on players who could not prevent relegation was a disastrous move.

Lemsagam adds that he has struggled to transfer money because the club's presumably fed-up bank do not want their business any more as a result of longstanding issues triggered before he took over. He promises that more funds will arrive in the next few days. 

There is a realisation that mistakes regarding recruitment have been made and that a more realistic budget is needed for the club's first campaign in League Two. Oldham have since agreed terms with former player Jose Baxter to much accolade from fans. However, whether they can pay the ex-Everton playmaker remains to be seen. 

Lemsagam, who says he took over the club, surrounded by Manchester giants United and City, because he identified its 'potential', does not want to make predictions but believes he can lead the club to profit this year. It would be some achievement. 

The Professional Footballers Association and the EFL, whose ownership test Lemsagam passed, are monitoring what appears to be a desperate situation. 

'I honestly fear for the future of the club,' one former player told Sportsmail.

In the meantime, the phone keeps ringing.

item.title: Stephan Lichtsteiner Q&A: Why has Unai Emery made this 34-year-old right back his first Arsenal signing?
item.description: Who is Lichtsteiner, and why has new manager Unai Emery decided to make him his first signing at the Emirates Stadium? Sportsmail examines his career so far and his style of play...
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal have confirmed Stephan Lichtsteiner will join the club on a free transfer once his Juventus contract expires.

The 34-year-old right back, captain of the Switzerland national team, will join up with his new club following the World Cup.

Who is Lichtsteiner, and why has new manager Unai Emery decided to make him his first signing at the Emirates Stadium? Sportsmail examines his career so far...


LICHTSTEINER: CAREER FACT FILE 

Age: 34

Position: Right back

Clubs: Grasshoppers (2001-2005), Lille (2005-2008), Lazio (2008-2011), Juventus (2011-2018), Arsenal (2018-)

Career club games: 565

Goals: 29; Assists: 46

International caps (Switzerland): 99

Honours: 7x Serie A (every season 2011-18), 5x Coppa Italia (2009, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018), 4x Italian Super Cup (2010, 2013, 2014, 2016), 2002/03 Swiss League 

Why has Emery started his Gunners career with an un-glamorous signing?

Certainly a veteran defender is not a player to get Arsenal fans leaping off the sofa, rushing to buy shirts with 'Lichtsteiner 12' on the back from the club shop. However players with the wealth of top level experience Lichtsteiner has are in short supply, having spent 10 years with top Italian clubs Lazio and Juventus.

Emery hinted that Lichtsteiner's wise head is his most valuable asset in his statement to the club website: 'Stephan brings huge experience and leadership to our squad. He's a player with great quality with a very positive and determined attitude. Stephan will improve us on and off the pitch.'

How important will he be off the pitch?

Arsenal's off-pitch figurehead, Per Mertesacker, has retired from playing, and although he remains at Arsenal in the backroom staff, having someone who has seen the footballing world and won a trophy cabinet's worth of silver among the playing staff will be immensely valuable.

Will he start for Arsenal?

Lichtsteiner will be competing with Hector Bellerin for the starting right back spot, and it would appear at first glance as if the pacy young Spaniard would be the top pick, especially as Lichtsteiner is not a different type of player - he loves to bomb forwards.

However, Emery mighty take a cue for Lichtsteiner's role in the Juventus team of 2016-17, when Dani Alves was the other right back. Lichtsteiner played only 73 minutes of Champions League football as Juve reached the final, but made 26 league appearances. A similar arrangement - one player starts in the league, the other in the cups - could be the way forward.

Can he cut it at the top level?

No matter how dominant Juventus might be domestically, winning seven league titles on the spin is not an achievement to be sniffed at. Lichtsteiner will bring a winning mentality to Arsenal - he is not used to finishing fifth or sixth, 30 or 40 points off the winners.

He also impressed against Real Madrid in the Champions League quarter final; coming off the bench after 17 minutes following an injury, his attacking, warrior-like style of battling play almost helped produce an all-time great comeback.

Add this to the fact he could make his 100th international appearance in Switzerland's World Cup opener against Brazil, and you have a player who lives at the top level.

Can he inspire a return to the top four?

Arsenal clearly need much more serious maintenance in order to seriously challenge for a first league title since 2004, but Lichtsteiner appears to be a step in the right direction.

item.title: Manchester City see £44m bid turned down by Juventus for Miralem Pjanic as he is 'increasingly essential to Massimiliano Allegri's plans'
item.description: Despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season, Pep Guardiola is not resting on his laurels and is looking to bolster his already formidable squad.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City have been hit with a huge setback in their pursuit of Miralem Pjanic as Juventus have rejected a £44million bid, according to reports in Italy. 

Despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season, becoming the first side to reach 100 points, Pep Guardiola is not resting on his laurels and is looking to bolster his already formidable squad.

And according to Italian publication Tuttosport, City have seen a £44million offer rejected with Juventus very keen on keeping one of their star players.


Tuttosport report that the Bosnian midfielder is increasingly essential to Massimiliano Allegri's plans for the future.

The Serie A giants see the offer as considerable but not enough to offload him to a European rival due to his importance in the heart of midfield.

Furthermore, the potential income from the sale of Pjanic would barely reach half of what Sergej Milinkovic-Savic would cost Juventus. 

Guardiola is attempting to improve his squad even further as they look to continue dominating English football and make a strong assault on the Champions League.

City were knocked out at the quarter-final stage of Europe's top-tier competition after losing against Liverpool over two legs.

item.title: Parma sporting director admits club 'cannot afford' to sign Mario Balotelli as they plan for return to Serie A
item.description: Parma sporting director Daniele Faggiano admits the club 'can't afford' to sign Mario Balotelli as he looks to put together a squad capable of avoiding relegation from Serie A next season.
item.content:encoded:
Parma sporting director Daniele Faggiano admits the club 'cannot afford' to sign Mario Balotelli as he looks to put together a squad capable of avoiding relegation from Serie A next season.

Balotelli is set to leave French side Nice on a free transfer when his contract expires at the end of June. 

Parma clinched promotion to Serie A last month just three years after being declared bankrupt, becoming the first Italian club to earn three successive promotions. 


However, a move to Stadio Ennio Tardini for Balotelli appears to be off the cards with Faggiano keen to extend the loan deals of three players rather than splash out on the Italian international.

'We want to stay up by putting together a good team,' Faggiano told on Radio Kiss Kiss Napoli.

'We're on good terms with Napoli, we'll talk to them and see if it's possible to keep [Amato] Ciciretti, [Armando] Anastasio and [Roberto] Insigne.

'We know very well the message we have to send, we've come from Serie D and it wasn't easy. We'll see what we can do for Insigne, and as for Balotelli he's a top player and could even end up at Napoli.

'He's a player whose quality is not up for discussion, but he has a high salary and we can't afford him.'

Balotelli played for Italy for the first time in four years during a 2-1 win over Saudi Arabia in Switzerland last week.

It is a reward for another fine season at Nice in which he scored 26 goals in 38 appearances.

item.title: Atletico Madrid 'eye Edinson Cavani should Barcelona target Antoine Griezmann leave'
item.description: Cavani has been linked with a switch to Atletico in the past and if the transfer went ahead he would join up with compatriots Diego Godin and Jose Gimenez. The 31-year-old scored 40 goals last season.
item.content:encoded:
Atletico Madrid are eyeing up a move for Paris Saint-Germain forward Edinson Cavani should Barcelona target Antoine Griezmann leave.

The Uruguay international is believed to be the La Liga club's No 1 target if their current striker departs, according to Mundo Deportivo.

The Spanish newspaper has reported that Cavani's agent met with Atletico a few weeks ago in the Spanish capital.


Cavani has been linked with a switch to Atletico in the past and if the transfer went ahead he would join up with compatriots Diego Godin and Jose Gimenez.

The 31-year-old scored 40 goals in 48 matches for PSG in the season just finished.

Cavani joined the Ligue 1 side back in 2013 and his contract expires in 2020.

The move to Atletico will not happen if Griezmann stays put.

It has been reported Griezmann has 'informed close friends' that he intends to remain at Atletico despite being courted by La Liga champions Barcelona.

item.title: Iceland star Aron Gunnarsson 'almost felt sorry' for England players during their Euro 2016 humiliation
item.description: Aron Gunnarsson has admitted he 'almost felt sorry' for England's players for the crushing pressure they felt during Iceland's shock win at the 2016 European Championship.
item.content:encoded:
Aron Gunnarsson has admitted he 'almost felt sorry' for England's players for the crushing pressure they felt during Iceland's shock win at the 2016 European Championship.

In one of the biggest humiliations in the history of the England national team, they lost 2-1 to Iceland in the last 16 of the tournament in France two years ago.

Gunnarsson, the Cardiff City midfielder, captained Iceland that night in Nice and reflects that the Three Lions froze because they were so heavily fancied to win.


He told The Players Tribune: 'I almost felt sorry for them. They were under so much pressure, and you could definitely tell.

'They were making simple mistakes, getting the basics wrong... they knew the trouble they would be in if they lost to Iceland.

'Everyone spoke about how bad England were, but watch the game again. Look at how organised we are. We run. We shut down space. We cover for each other.

'When the game was over, I sprinted toward our fans so quickly that I forgot to shake hands with the England players. So if you guys are reading this... sorry!

'And, then … well, I know this may sound weird, because I’m this Icelander with all these tattoos and a beard and all that.

'But as we celebrated, I wanted to cry. Honestly. When we did the Viking Clap with our fans, shivers ran down my spine.'

Having arrived at their first major tournament with minimal expectations, Iceland finished second in their group behind Hungary, being paired with England after scoring a last-minute winner against Austria.

Though Wayne Rooney fired England ahead from the penalty spot four minutes in, Iceland equalised through Ragnar Sigurdsson two minutes later before Kolbeinn Sigthorsson scored what proved to be the winner on 18 minutes.

Gunnarsson, who has made 77 appearances for Iceland, has been included in the squad for the World Cup in Russia having helped his club Cardiff win promotion to the Premier League.

item.title: 'All that's missing is that they say Firmino caught a cold from one of my drops of sweat': Sergio Ramos hits back at claims he deliberately injured Liverpool duo Mo Salah and Loris Karius in the Champions League final
item.description: Ramos also suggested that Salah, who went off with a shoulder injury after being pulled to the ground by the Spaniard, could have taken painkilling injections and played the second half.
item.content:encoded:
Sergio Ramos has ridiculed the reaction to his clashes with Loris Karius and Mo Salah during Real Madrid's Champions League victory over Liverpool.

The Real defender made light of the incident with Karius despite Sportsmail revealing on Tuesday that the Liverpool goalkeeper suffered concussion after a clash with Ramos before making two huge errors to gift Real a 3-1 triumph in Kiev last month.

Ramos also suggested that Salah, who went off with a shoulder injury in the 30th minute after being pulled to the ground by the Spaniard, could have taken painkilling injections and played the second half. 


Speaking in Madrid as Spain made their final World Cup preparations before flying to Russia, Ramos began with his clash with Salah that ended the attacker's participation in the final.

The Real captain said: 'Bloody hell, they've given the Salah thing a lot of coverage. I didn't want to talk about it because everything then gets magnified.

'Looking at the incident, he grabs my arm first and I fell to the other side. The injury is to his other arm. And they said that I put him in a judo hold.'

Moving on to the Karius clash, he added: 'The goalkeeper says that he was dazed because of a clash with me.

'All that's missing is that they say Firmino caught a cold from one of my drops of sweat.' 

Karius appeared to be elbowed in the head by Ramos, who had collided with Liverpool defender Virgil van Dijk as they challenged for a Madrid corner.

The German goalkeeper could be heard on television screaming at the impact as he went down. 

He did not receive any treatment from Liverpool's medical staff on the pitch and seconds later threw the ball into Karim Benzema's path for Real's opener. He later allowed Gareth Bale's shot from 30 yards to slip through his hands for Real's third goal.

Returning to the Salah incident, which threatens the Egyptian's involvement in the World Cup, Ramos claimed to have made peace with the player after the game but suggested his immediate substitution was an exaggerated response to their collision.

He said: 'I exchanged messages with Salah after the match and it was fine. He could have played on if he had taken a painkilling injection for the second half. I have done that sometimes.

'It really wasn't all that much but when it's Ramos that does something like this, more gets made of it.'

The four-time Champions League winner added: 'I don't know if it's because I've been at Madrid for so many years and winning for so long that people look at it differently.'

Ramos comments will anger those Liverpool supporters who have called for the final to be replayed after the revelations surrounding the injury to Karius.

Liverpool's medical staff sent the 24-year-old to Boston to see a specialist at Massachusetts General Hospital, where a brain scan revealed he had suffered a blackout and experienced concussion moments before Real's first goal.

item.title: Manchester United sign £52m Fred on five-year deal as Brazil midfielder gets hug from £198m Neymar during World Cup training session
item.description: Manchester United have agreed a five year contract with Brazil midfielder Fred. The £52million signing from Shakhtar Donetsk travelled to United's Mayfair offices in London to complete the formalities
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have agreed a five-year contract with Brazil midfielder Fred.

The £52million signing from Shakhtar Donetsk travelled to United's Mayfair offices in London to complete the formalities of his move before taking part in Brazil training at Tottenham's training ground.

Fred received a hug from Neymar shortly after the announcement. The Paris Saint-Germain ace knows a thing or two about big-money moves having left Barcelona to the French capital in a world record £198m move last summer.   


The final announcement could still be delayed by the transfer of international paperwork involving the Brazilian FA but United boss Jose Mourinho has secured his man as he prepares to leave for the World Cup in Russia. 

The Selecao have one final friendly in a bid to fine tune their plans for this summer's tournament as they take on Austria at the Ernst-Happel-Stadion in Vienna on Sunday. 

Spirits were high in training on Tuesday and both boss Tite and Fred will be relieved to finally have his future sorted after months of speculation. 

Fred left Brazil's team following Sunday's win over Croatia at Anfield to have the first part of his medical and a look around the United's training complex before undergoing club publicity photographs on Monday and heading to London with his agents Fabio Mello and Gilberto Silva.

United are also completing the finer details of terms with Porto for full-back Diogo Dalot, who is due in London to sign his contract, also expected to be for five years.

Jose Mourinho likes the idea that the 19-year-old looks comfortable at left back and could well start him in that position as he looks to develop him into the successor to Antonio Valencia at right back. 

United have still to agree a fee with Juventus for Matteo Darmian.

The Italian side thought they could deal at £11.5m but United have asked for closer to £17m.

Inter Milan have also shown an interest in Daley Blind as they look to replace Joao Cancelo.

United retain interest in Real Madrid's Gareth Bale who is expecting his representatives to discuss his future with the European champions next week.

Marko Arnautovic of West Ham has also been discussed by United as cover for Romelu Lukaku though West Ham would want in excess of £50m.

item.title: Wolves ready to sell Benik Afobe to Stoke City - FOUR days after paying £10m to sign him from Bournemouth
item.description: Wolves are on the brink of selling Benik Afobe to Stoke City just four days after they paid £10million to make his loan from Bournemouth permanent, it is understood.
item.content:encoded:
Wolves are on the brink of selling Benik Afobe to Stoke City just four days after they paid £10million to make his loan from Bournemouth permanent, it is understood.

The 25-year-old aided Wolves' promotion bid after joining them on February 1 by firing in six Championship goals in 16 appearances.

It came as little surprise to see them activate their purchase option last Friday, but it now appears the Premier League newcomers did so with the intention of turning a quick profit. Indeed, Afobe is in advanced talks to join Stoke in a deal worth £12m.


Afobe initially made his name with Wolves following a £2m arrival from Arsenal in January 2015. Bournemouth forked out £10m to sign him a year later, but he struggled to replicate his fine Championship form in the top flight.

His 11 goals in 70 appearances for the Cherries may have gone a long way to making Wolves' decision to sell easier as they are looking for proven Premier League quality after winning the Championship last season.

Stoke, meanwhile, are looking to rebuild their squad with players with experience in football's second tier following relegation after a decade in the Premier League. Gary Rowett will be given money with the aim of bouncing straight back up.

Since joining Wolves from Arsenal in 2015, Afobe has scored a respectable 28 goals in 62 Championship appearances and has also cut himself a reputation as a tireless worker at the top end of the team.

His strange set of circumstances will seal a small profit for Wolves, who are looking to strengthen significantly in order to establish themselves in the top flight. Most recently, they took up the option to sign Porto's Willy Boly after a loan spell.

Super agent Jorge Mendes, who is connected to the club through their owners, could help them make additions and reports in Italy claim they are in talks to sign Valencia star Joao Cancelo for £35m. The right back is represented by Mendes.

item.title: 'Of course I have my own idea': Man United target Toby Alderweireld hints that he could go - but admits Tottenham will 'decide future'
item.description: Toby Alderweireld says any transfer this summer is entirely in the hands of Tottenham - but hinted he has different ideas about his future. He has been linked with a move away from Spurs this summer.
item.content:encoded:
Toby Alderweireld says any transfer this summer is entirely in the hands of Tottenham Hotspur - but hinted he has different ideas about his future. 

Alderweireld has been linked with a move away from Spurs this summer, with Manchester United among the clubs said to be keen on the centre back. 

A number of potential deals for Alderweireld have been touted, from a £40million swoop to a potential swap to United with Anthony Martial.


The Belgium international, who missed five months of the 2017-18 campaign with a hamstring injury, admitted he has been considering his future options. 

Alderweireld told Belgian newspaper de Zontag: 'I have another two years contract, so Tottenham decide about my future. Of course I have my own idea, but that is not the case now.

'The past season was tough, but I'm glad that I could play the last four matches. That means that I am ready for the World Cup.'

Following his injury, Alderweireld returned to first-team action in mid-April, just in time to be named in Belgium's squad for Russia.

He played 90 minutes of their first warm-up match, a 0-0 draw against Portugal which saw the Red Devils booed off by their home fans at the final whistle. 

He is likely to feature in Belgium's three Group G matches in Russia, against Panama, Tunisia and England.

item.title: Gianluigi Buffon suspended for three matches by UEFA following red card meltdown during Champions League quarter-final vs Real Madrid
item.description: Buffon was sent off in the second leg of the tie after protesting to referee Michael Oliver about the Englishman's decision to award a stoppage-time penalty against Juventus.
item.content:encoded:
Gianluigi Buffon has been banned for three matches for his red card and comments about referee Michael Oliver after Juventus' Champions League quarter-final defeat against Real Madrid.

The goalkeeper was dismissed when he aggressively confronted the Premier League official following the injury-time award of a penalty against his side, leading to Real's winning goal.

Buffon then launched a verbal attack when he said that Oliver had 'a rubbish bin where his heart should be'. Both the referee and his wife, Lucy, were the subject of online abuse and had to be offered police support. 


But UEFA have finally acted to punish the 40-year-old, who has since left Juventus but will be suspended for three games should his new club take part in European competition next season. The ban is one game for his red card and two for his 'general principles of conduct'.

Buffon spoke about the incident after being hit with the UEFA charge last month. Still, though, he tried to justify his actions.

'I still don't understand why the referee sent me off - and you, rather than focusing on my comments, should look at behaviour from the official that was not really consistent,' he said. 

'I said a few days later that I went over the line and that's evident. I am extremely sorry about that, as over 23 years of my Champions League career, I was never sent off or suspended, so I feel that I behaved fairly and in a sporting manner with everyone. 

'It was a particular situation and a few days later I confessed the Buffon of that day, with the sentiments and feelings of that night, couldn't help but say those things.

'A few days later, clearly, I was sorry to have 'offended' the referee, because at the end of the day he is a human being who does a very difficult job. 

'If I'd seen him two days later, I'd have hugged Michael Oliver and apologised, but also said he could have been a bit calmer in such an important game for us and for me.'

Buffon was incensed when, with Juve having clawed back a three-goal deficit from the first leg, Oliver pointed to the spot in the 93rd minute after Mehdi Benatia's clumsy challenge on Lucas Vazquez inside the six-yard area.

Pundits and former referees later said that Oliver was correct to award the penalty, converted by Cristiano Ronaldo after a lengthy delay during which Buffon was sent off. 

FORMER REFEREE GRAHAM POLL:

UEFA have blown a golden chance. They should have banned Gianluigi Buffon for a significant period — enough to deter any other player from acting as he did.

The Juventus goalkeeper was rightly sent off by English referee Michael Oliver for prolonged and vehement objections to Real Madrid being given a penalty. Buffon was not content with objecting on the field, he continued his verbal assault after the match and the day after!

Abuse and threats suffered by Oliver and his wife Lucy can't be blamed directly on Buffon but it is hard not to believe that they are linked. If players (and managers) accepted decisions, fans would be less inclined to 'have a go' in the street.

UEFA like to be consistent with punishments for misconduct — hence Buffon getting a three-match ban, one for the offence and two for the outburst after the game.

But now they are tied to applying an additional two-match ban when the next abuser unloads on a referee.

'The UEFA Control, Ethics and Disciplinary Body has decided to suspend the Juventus Football Club player Gianluigi Buffon for three (3) UEFA competition matches for which he would be otherwise eligible,' the governing body said in a statement.

item.title: Arsenal sign 34-year-old defender Stephan Lichtsteiner on a free as Unai Emery hails his new player's 'huge experience and leadership'
item.description: Lichtsteiner won the Serie A title in each of his seven seasons in Turin, but moves to London and will wear the No 12 shirt. He is first signing since Unai Emery succeeded Arsene Wenger.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal have confirmed the signing of veteran full-back Stephan Lichtsteiner on a free transfer from Juventus. 

The Switzerland international becomes the first Gunners signing confirmed since Unai Emery succeeded Arsene Wenger as manager.

Emery told the club website: 'Stephan brings huge experience and leadership to our squad. He's a player with great quality with a very positive and determined attitude. Stephan will improve us on and off the pitch.' 


LICHTSTEINER: CAREER FACT FILE 

Age: 34

Position: Right back

Clubs: Grasshoppers (2001-2005), Lille (2005-2008), Lazio (2008-2011), Juventus (2011-2018), Arsenal (2018-)

Career club games: 565

Goals: 29; Assists: 46

International caps (Switzerland): 99

Honours: 7x Serie A (every season 2011-18), 5x Coppa Italia (2009, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018), 4x Italian Super Cup (2010, 2013, 2014, 2016), 2002/03 Swiss League 

Arsenal teased the move by asking fans on Twitter to name the nine Arsenal players going to this summer's World Cup - with Lichtsteiner being No 9. 

The move was then confirmed with a short video clip of Lichtsteiner, wearing an Arsenal polo shirt, saying 'nothing gets past us'. 

He then posted a message to Twitter saying: 'Happy and honoured to be a Gunner! Will work hard and passionately day in and day out to achieve our sporting objectives and to win trophies with this great club!'

New team-mate Mohamed Elneny also welcomed Lichtsteiner to the club on social media, retweeting him with the statement 'welcome on board'.

Photos from Arsenal's London Colney base showed Lichtsteiner in his new club kit, and being greeted by former player Robert Pires.

Lichtsteiner, 34, won the Serie A title in each of his seven seasons in Turin, but moves to London and will wear the No 12 shirt. 

He made over 250 appearances for Juve and will win his 100th cap for Switzerland - who he has captained since 2016 - this Friday in a friendly against Japan.

If he does not play in that match, Lichtsteiner could mark his century of Swiss caps in their World Cup opener against Brazil on June 17.

Arsenal have not confirmed the length of Lichtsteiner's contract, and he will join the Gunners following the expiration of his Juventus deal this month.

Lichtsteiner will compete with Hector Bellerin for the starting right back spot in Emery's Gunners side.

item.title: Didier Drogba and Newcastle lead tributes to Cheick Tiote on the one-year anniversary of his sudden death
item.description: On the anniversary of Cheick Tiote's tragic death, compatriot Didier Drogba has shown his respects by sharing an image of the pair together during an Ivory Coast match.
item.content:encoded:
On the anniversary of Cheick Tiote's tragic death, compatriot Didier Drogba has shown his respects by sharing an image of the pair together during an Ivory Coast match.

Tiote died suddenly on 5 June 2017 after suffering from a cardiac arrest. He collapsed during a training session in China at just 30 years old.

He had been playing for Beijing Enterprises having moved from Newcastle just four months earlier, who have also given a tribute to their former midfielder.


Accompanying the image, Drogba said: 'Already a year since you left us, miss you my soldier.' 

Newcastle also commemorated the anniversary of their former midfielder's death by giving their condolences to his family.

They said: 'A year ago today, former Newcastle United midfielder Cheick Tioté tragically passed away at the age of just 30. Our thoughts are with Cheick's family.'

Tiote made 139 appearances across six and half seasons in the North East. His only goal for Newcastle was a memorable equaliser as they came back from 4-0 down at home to Arsenal. 

A year ago today, former #NUFC midfielder Cheick Tioté tragically passed away at the age of just 30. Our thoughts are with Cheick’s family. pic.twitter.com/e5vvVNAmXb

— Newcastle United FC (@NUFC) June 5, 2018

Tiote and Drogba made up part of a golden generation for the Ivory Coast, along with Yaya and Kolo Toure, Solomon Kalour, Emmanuel Eboue and Gervinho among others.

In 2015 they won the African Cup of Nations for the first time in 13 years and only the second time in the nation's history.

Tiote was also a key part of the squad that qualified for the 2010 and 2014 World Cup's. They have only reached the finals on three occasions and did not reach the 2018 tournament in Russia. 

At the time of his sudden death, Newcastle manager Rafa Benitez said: 'It is with great sadness that I have this afternoon learned of Cheick's death.

'In all the time that I have known him, he was a true professional, dedicated and above all, a great man. Our hearts go out to his family and friends at such a sad time.'

item.title: Man United have moved for former City targets twice in six months to sign Alexis Sanchez and Fred - so can they help to bridge 19-point gap to their Premier League rivals?
item.description: The last two occasions these two neighbours have gone head-to-head in the transfer market, it has been the club from Old Trafford that has won the battle.
item.content:encoded:
The final Premier League table was emphatic enough: Manchester City 100 points, Manchester United 81 points. City's goal difference +79, United's +40. City champions of England, United nowhere near.

Yet the last two occasions these neighbours have gone head-to-head in the transfer market, it has been the club from Old Trafford that has won the battle.

In January, Alexis Sanchez was poised to become the latest addition to City's fearsome forward line. Personal terms had been agreed with the Chilean's representatives and Arsenal were offered £20million for him.


Given that Sanchez's contract was due to expire this summer, it seemed to represent good business for all parties.

It was then that United sauntered up, flashed the cash to Sanchez and gazumped their neighbours by persuading him to sign.

Now it's happened again. City had been long-standing front-runners to sign Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk, yet the Brazilian midfielder is about to complete a £53m transfer to United instead.

Pep Guardiola had sanctioned a bid for Fred back in January, but Shakhtar were reluctant to sell such a prized asset mid-season. Nonetheless, City believed they could get their man in summer.

Yet on Tuesday, we saw Fred being driven into United's Carrington training complex in a black Mercedes to undergo a medical, which went smoothly. He is expected to be officially announced soon.

Given how prepared and ruthless City usually are in getting their summer transfer business concluded, especially useful in a World Cup year when transfer fees can inflate overnight, this came as a surprise.

So twice in the space of six months, United have managed to snatch one of City's primary transfer targets from right under their noses. And this despite City's evident superiority on the field right now.

The balance of power in Manchester has been in flux since the takeover by Sheik Mansour and his Abu Dhabi United group in 2008 transformed the landscape of English football in the blink of an eye.

Confirmation that United faced a genuine and long-term challenge to their Premier League dominance came just hours after news of the takeover broke when they broke the British transfer record to sign Robinho for £32.5m.

During the first few years under Emirati control, City were only too happy to flex their financial muscles, blowing their rivals out of the water when it came to transfer fees and wage packets.

Emmanuel Adebayor and Mario Balotelli were among the statement signings, but the most high-profile was City's success in luring Carlos Tevez across the city from United by offering him a substantially bigger salary.

United and City jousted for the league title for five years, but the traditional powerhouse club slipped back following the 2013 retirement of manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

Since then, City have been the pre-eminent force in the Premier League, winning two titles since United last lifted the trophy. They have also won the League Cup three times since 2013.

But despite City's burgeoning success and market appeal, United continue to hold the title of the world's richest football club.

Their enormous worldwide commercial appeal means they tussle with European champions Real Madrid for the top spot on Deloitte's football rich list, while City remain a distant fifth.

With their finances secured by a mammoth £750m, 10-year kit sponsorship deal with adidas and burnished by lasting popularity around the globe plus a return to Champions League football, United can well afford to splash the cash.

Recent seasons have seen them spend big in the transfer market on the likes of Paul Pogba, Romelu Lukaku, Henrikh Mkhitaryan, Anthony Martial, Memphis Depay, Sanchez and now Fred.

As they try and bridge that 19-point gap to City, United haven't worried too much that Sanchez is earning £600,000 a week all told or that Fred's asking price was £53m despite him not playing a single game in Europe's top leagues.

The big spending sends out a message that United remain world football's commercial powerhouse even if some would say their desperation to catch up means they'll pay whatever it takes, breaking their wage structure again and again.

If that sounds a little like City a decade or so ago, recent events have indicated that City themselves have taken a different tack.

Believing that they had an outline for the Sanchez deal agreed last summer, they duly backed out when the goalposts changed and his wage demands were jacked up in January.

With Guardiola and director of football Txiki Begiristain making the decisions, City stuck to their guns and refused to pay more, allowing United to swoop.

They believed that smashing their wage structure to bring in Sanchez would upset the harmony inside the dressing room - and they were probably right.  

They spent money on the defender Aymeric Laporte instead and, with such a superb forward line, they still won the Premier League at a canter without Sanchez.

It could certainly be argued that City took a stand of principle when more money was demanded, even if it did appear United had gazumped them in the PR war.

The situation with Fred has been slightly different. Shakhtar turned down City's bid in January but it is believed Guardiola still wanted him as Fernandinho's replacement.

But when United's interest became apparent, City switched their attentions to the Napoli midfielder Jorginho and they're hopeful to conclude a deal before the start of the World Cup.

Given events over Sanchez, it seems strange that City didn't take on their rivals. They too have the capability to offer an attractive package to any player in the world.  

With Fred being City's target for so long, it appears United have trumped them for the second time in a matter of months. It proves United still have that appeal of old as well as the financial clout.

Of course, City won't care one jot if they canter away with next season's Premier League.

item.title: President Emmanuel Macron meets France squad as he becomes latest world leader to wish his side good luck ahead of the World Cup
item.description: France will hope to go all the way at the World Cup, and they have the backing of some significant figures. Deschamps' squad were greeted by French President Emmanuel Macron
item.content:encoded:
France will hope to go all the way at the World Cup this summer, and they have the backing of some very significant figures.  

Didier Deschamps' squad were greeted by French President Emmanuel Macron at their Clairefontaine base on Tuesday.

President Macron posed for a picture for the squad, with French Sports Minister Laura Flessel-Colovic and French Football Federation President Noel Le Graet also in attendance.

Macron became the latest world leader to meet his country's national team.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel, for instance, met Joachim Low's squad on Sunday, while on Tuesday new Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez wished the likes of Diego Costa and Andres Iniesta good luck ahead of the tournament.

Furthermore, Portugal Prime Minster Antonio Costa met members of Fernando Santos' team.


France players, including Antoine Griezmann, Paul Pogba and Kylian Mbappe, seemed delighted to meet the dignitaries.

Tottenham goalkeeper Hugo Lloris was also among the players to speak to President Macron. 

FRANCE FIXTURES 

Friendly:

Saturday - United States - Stade des Lumieres - 8pm

World Cup:

June 16 - Australia - Kazan Arena - 11am

June 21 - Peru - Ekaterinburg Arena - 4pm

June 26 - Denmark - Luzhniki Stadium - 3pm 

France's preparations for the tournament are going well as they prevailed past the Republic of Ireland and Italy in friendlies.

Next up is another preparation game against the United States on Saturday as Deschamps sees to ensure his team are in top shape.

That is France's final fixture before the real action gets underway in Russia.

Deschamps' team are in Group C at the tournament, where they will play Australia, Peru and Denmark.

item.title: Leroy Sane tells Germany's World Cup squad to 'go get that title!' as he expresses disappointment over shock exclusion from Joachim Low's final 23
item.description: Leroy Sane has demanded his Germany team-mates 'Go get that title!' in Russia following the Manchester City winger's shock omission from Joachim Low's World Cup squad.
item.content:encoded:
Leroy Sane has demanded his Germany team-mates 'Go get that title!' in Russia following the Manchester City winger's shock omission from Joachim Low's World Cup squad.

The 22-year-old enjoyed an instrumental campaign as City romped to thePremier League title and won the League Cup, scoring 14 goals and assisting 19 more.

He was the obvious choice to be named PFA Young Player of the Year, one of Pep Guardiola’s most lethal attacking weapons, but Low deemed him surplus to requirements this summer. 


Despite admitting his 'disappointment' at the decision, Sane urged his national team colleagues to once again win the trophy they lifted in Brazil four years ago.

'Thank you so much everyone for your encouraging messages yesterday and today,' Sane wrote on Twitter.

'I'm obviously disappointed I won't participate in the World Cup but I have to accept this decision and I'll give it my all to bounce back stronger!

'Nothing but the best of success to the DFB Team in Russia. Go get that title!' 

Ultimately Bayer Leverkusen winger Julian Brandt was selected in Sane’s place as Low cut his provisional squad by four and the German boss explained his decision considerably on Monday.

‘That was a very close decision, which was made in favour of Brandt,’ Low explained. ‘If it was a 100m race, it would have been a photo finish. You have to look at the big picture so we have a variable and well-balanced team prepared for all eventualities. Draxler, Reus and Muller are set.

‘Both Sane and Brandt have big qualities, both are good in the one-on-one duels. Brandt was at the Confederations Cup, had some strong games there, and put in good shifts in the training camp too.

‘Sane is a huge talent, no doubt, and he will be back with the team in September. He had not arrived in international matches yet. Maybe that tipped the balance.’

item.title: Paulinho is statistically the best player on the FIFA 18 World Cup mode
item.description: Despite his high overall of 87, many players may overlook including Paulinho in their squads - not realising that they're missing out on the best non-Icon player in the new mode.
item.content:encoded:
The FIFA 18 World Cup mode has been out for over a week now and Ultimate Team players have begun to build ridiculous squads on the mode.

Despite his high overall of 87, many players may overlook including Paulinho in their squads - not realising that they're missing out on the best non-Icon player in the mode.

When adding up all players' total statistics in the game (not just the ones that appear on the card), Paulinho remains supreme with none of his stats in the red.

His stats add up to 2244, taking him above Cristiano Ronaldo, Lionel Messi, Paul Pogba, Luis Suarez and even a lot of the Icons including Brazilian Ronaldo and Ronaldinho.

Paulinho is incredibly balanced with excellent stats in every part of his game. His 77 pace isn't amazing but it's enough for a central midfielder and he makes up for it in other areas. 

His 86 ball control and reactions means he can boss the midfield while his 81 interceptions and stand tackling is very helpful defensively. Paulinho can even produce a surprise goal with 86 shot power and 83 long shots.

He'll score plenty of headers too with 98 jumping and 83 heading and will never tire with 99 stamina.

If you're building a South American team or just need a solid option on the bench, Paulinho is more than the man for the job, now you just need to hope you can pack him.

item.title: Joachim Low blasted for dropping Sane... by the sprinklers at training! Germany boss gets a soaking as his final picks focus on World Cup
item.description: Low's men, as reigning world champions, enter the competition as favourites and will be looking to send a message to their rivals after that shocking defeat by Austria on Saturday.
item.content:encoded:
Germany boss Joachim Low's soaking by a sprinkler on Tuesday could have been cruel payback for his savage axing of Leroy Sane from his World Cup squad.

Low announced his final 23-man squad for the tournament in Russia on Monday which saw Sane - last season's PFA Young Player of the Year - excluded.

It was a controversial decision that sparked uproar on social media. However, the show must go on, and those who were selected must get to work. 


On a sunny day in southern Tyrol - a province of north-east Italy - Low was caught out as a set of sprinklers went off during the training session.

Low stood among his players as the water came bursting out of the earth to spray him directly in the face. That's one way to cool his frustrations after last Saturday's defeat by Austria.

The 2-1 defeat at the Worthersee Stadion may have planted just a small piece of doubt in supporters' minds that they are not so indestructible.

They will face Saudi Arabia in their final warm-up match at the BayArena on Friday, where they will attempt to salvage their World Cup-winning reputation.   

Matthias Ginter and Thomas Muller were both pictured dragging weighted bags across the turf of Germany's southern Tyrol training base. Punishment? Maybe. Low would have been displeased with the performance in Austria, and would have wanted to motivate his players as they seek to defend their crown

Fresh from his retaining his captaincy, Manuel Neuer led his team-mates out on to the training ground for the first time since the squad was confirmed on Monday.

He has recovered from a foot injury that ruled him out for almost all of last season to reclaim the No 1 shirt from the grasp of Marc-Andre ter Stegen.

Julian Draxler, who was the lucky individual preferred by Low to Sane in the final selection process, was another looking to back up his manager's faith in him. He can do that by helping Germany race to victory in Leverkusen, as is expected.
item.dc:abstract: The Germans face fellow World Cup participants Saudi Arabia at the BayArena on Friday and were put through their paces on Tuesday as they look to get salvage some form heading into the World Cup. On a sunny day in southern Tyrol - a province of north-east Italy - Low was caught non-the-wiser as a set of sprinklers went off randomly during the training session.

item.title: Lionel Messi bulking up to carry the weight of a nation as Argentina superstar works on his strength ahead of World Cup glory bid
item.description: It was another day of preparation for Lionel Messi as he and his Argentina team-mates continue their pre-World Cup boot camp in a bid to land their hands on the biggest prize in football.
item.content:encoded:
It was another day of preparation for Lionel Messi in the familiar surroundings of Barcelona, as he and his Argentina team-mates continue their pre-World Cup boot camp in a bid to land their hands on the biggest prize in football.

The hopes of a nation will be pinned on one man and Messi will be well aware that this could be his last chance of silverware on the international stage.

The Barcelona star was tasked with carrying weight on his shoulders in Argentina's training session on Tuesday. Come June 14 he will be tasked with carrying a lot more. 


Argentina's other stars will be hoping they can take some of the load as Sergio Aguero, Pablo Dybala and Angel di Maria all trained alongside Messi.

Manchester City's centre-back Nicolas Otamendi also looked in good condition and he will be hoping to take some of his Premier League form into the World Cup.

After all, it is defensively that Argentina have most often been vulnerable. Perhaps finally, alongside Federico Fazio who reached the Champions League semi-finals with Roma, they will have a defensive pairing capable of helping their side go the distance.

Now in the closing stages of their World Cup warm-up regime, they will play a final friendly against Israel in Jerusalem before travelling on to Russia.

ARGENTINA FIXTURES

Friendlies 

June 9 - vs Israel (Jerusalem) 

World Cup

June 16 - vs Iceland (Moscow)

June 21 - vs Croatia (Nizhny Novgorod) 

June 26 - vs Nigeria (Saint Petersburg) 

It could well be Messi's last shot at a major international trophy, which has continued to elude him. 

He threatened to retire from international football following Argentina's defeat by Chile in the 2016 Copa America final, but came back to help his country qualify for the World Cup. 

The forward will turn 31 during the tournament and it's unlikely he will play in any further World Cups, leaving this as his final shot at emulating Diego Maradona.

Once again, he will carry the weight of his country on his shoulders as he bids to add a trophy to his collection that would surely cement him as the greatest player of all time.

item.title: Lionel Messi, Mohamed Salah and Paul Pogba joined by David Beckham and Jose Mourinho in star-studded adidas advert ahead of the World Cup
item.description: The race to be the most noticeable brand at the World Cup is on after adidas began their war with Nike by releasing a star-studded advert including the biggest names in the sport.
item.content:encoded:
The race to be the most noticeable brand at the World Cup is on after adidas began their usual war with Nike by releasing a star-studded advert including the biggest names in the sport.

The German sportswear giant took advantage of their myriad sponsorship deals with football stars by inviting Barcelona's Lionel Messi to appear alongside Mohamed Salah, Paul Pogba, Luis Suarez and David Beckham to name but a few.

Mesut Ozil, Dele Alli, Gabriel Jesus, Jesse Lingard, Javier Hernandez, David de Gea and Roberto Firmino also feature briefly alongside Zinedine Zidane and Jose Mourinho, who were acting as managers in the advert's cage match.


WHO IS IN THE VIDEO? 

Footballers: Bernardo Silva (Manchester City), Lionel Messi (Barcelona) Chicharito (West Ham), Gabriel Jesus (Manchester City), David De Gea (Manchester United), Dele Alli (Tottenham), Jesse Lingard (Manchester United), Lindsey Horan (USA),  Florencia Galarza (Kith Cobras) Luis Suarez (Barcelona), Mohamed Salah (Liverpool), Mesut Ozil (Arsenal), Paul Pogba (Manchester United)

Other stars: A$AP Ferg (Musician), Caitlyn Schrepfer (Freestyler), Caroline Wozniacki (Tennis player),  Karlie Kloss (model), Von Miller (NFL player), David Beckham (former footballer), Pharrell Williams (Musician), Stormzy (Musician), Damian Lillard (NBA player)

During the advert, women's freestyler Caitlyn Schrepfer shows England's Lingard a clean set of heels before combining with Salah and teeing up Alli to hit a sumptuous volley into the net.

Pogba, who has had to absorb intense criticism from the French media recently, appears to play the biggest role as he is given the task of controlling the official World Cup ball while wearing the company's new Predator Tango 18+ Street trainers. 

Although he may be in poor form on the pitch, he displays breathtaking control with the Telstar football, which despite its retro look boasts a state-of-the-art thermal bond technology which gives it a seamless surface for pinpoint accuracy and low water absorption.

The 90-second 'Create the Answer' advert is not just limited to footballers. 

It also features Pharrell Williams, tennis star Caroline Wozniacki, NFL player Von Miller, NBA's Damian Lillard, model Karlie Kloss and rappers A$AP Ferg and Stormzy. 

Throughout the advert, A$AP Ferg repeats the phrase 'creativity is the answer'. In total, 56 different 'creators' appear in the advert for what adidas claim to be their most personal campaign ever.

This summer's World Cup begins on June 14 with Russia's game against Saudi Arabia and culminates with the final on July 15.

item.title: Real Madrid's 5 key contenders to replace Zinedine Zidane… so, will Arsene Wenger make an incredible return at the Bernabeu?
item.description: Replacing Zidane is proving more difficult for Real Madrid owing to the unavailability of Mauricio Pochettino. Sportsmail looks at the five front-runners for the hottest hot-seat in football.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid don’t usually hang around when they bring in a new manager. 

When Juande Ramos took over in 2008 he practically came in one door, stage left, to do his presentation press conference, as the sacked Bernd Schuster made his exit, stage right through another door, having just given his farewell conference.

Similarly it only took them 24 hours to replace Rafa Benitez with Zinedine Zidane in January 2016. 

But now replacing Zidane is proving more difficult owing to the unavailability of the man they really wanted, Mauricio Pochettino. 

Sportsmail looks at the five front-runners for the hottest hot-seat in football and the pros and cons of each potential appointment.

Arsene Wenger 

The man that Arsenal got tired of and finally ushered out the door. 

The coach who took them from the Champions League into the Europa League and couldn’t beat Diego Simeone’s team despite a man advantage for half the tie. 

That’s what the fans will say if he ends up getting the job. As a stop-gap while some of the younger options come of age the Wenger option is not as crazy as it sounds. 

But fans would still hate the idea at first and President Florentino Perez would be going back to someone who – when he was at his peak – turned him down on more than one occasion. 

The pill could be sweetened by the presence of a younger more dynamic man such as Raul who the supporters relate to. 

FOR: Experienced and available

AGAINST: Hard sell to supporters

 

Massimiliano Allegri 

Impeccable record in terms of honours, temperament and statesmanship.

He’s under contract at Juventus but only until 2020 so buying him out would be cheaper than wrenching Pochettino from that 2023 deal.

Supporters would not throw any street parties if he was appointed. He was in charge of the Juve team that Zidane’s Real Madrid destroyed in last year’s Champions League final – hardly the greatest reference. 

But he would be seen as a safe pair of hands as the club try to steady themselves after Zidane’s unexpected departure

FOR: Great record

AGAINST: Juventus would want compensation

 

Guti 

An immensely talented but ultimately inconsistent and underachieving midfielder in his day, Guti has turned into an unexpected coaching success within Real Madrid’s youth academy. 

LAST FIVE REAL MADRID MANAGERS 

Zinedine Zidane - 2016-2018

Rafa Benitez - 2015-2016

Carl Ancelotti - 2013-2015

Jose Mourinho - 2010-2013

Manuel Pellegrini - 2009-2010 

He now wants to move to another level but the obvious next step to coach the club’s B-team ‘Real Madrid Castilla’ is currently blocked because Santiago Solari has the job. 

Guti is more highly-rated than Solari and could leapfrog him into the top job. 

He was a team-mate of Zidane although it’s hard to see him commanding the same respect in the current dressing room. 

He would be a massive gamble. But the fact that old head Fernando Hierro has been sounded out about being his No 2 shows the club are taking his credentials seriously.

He has been linked to St Mirren although sources in Madrid say he’s unlikely to end up there.

FOR: Talented and already at the club

AGAINST: Inexperienced and might struggle to win over dressing room

 

Michael Laudrup 

He has all the old Zidane charm and there would be promise of Real Madrid playing some of the fantasy football he made his trademark as a player. 

On the minus side he has been around the managerial block with limited success outside of Denmark. 

But that might not bother Perez who likes the idea of another elegant sharp-suited great from the club’s past running the team. 

He wants the job and it would be a straightforward option because he is a free agent.

FOR: Would look the part and could start tomorrow

AGAINST: No record of winning big trophies in Europe

 

Michel 

The Spanish Alan Curbishley, as in, always linked to every job. 

Sacked by Malaga last season. That's not the greatest reference although they are a basket-case club at the moment and they still dropped like a stone without him into the second division.

He is another one who knows the club having previously coached Castilla and been a director of the youth academy.

He was also one of the club’s finest players. Has fallen in and out of favour over the years with the Bernabeu powers that be but would be a safe pair of hands likely to tow the party line and allow the club to be led from the boardroom.

FOR: Available, charismatic and politically on message

AGAINST: Only ever won trophies in Greece

item.title: Sky faces battle over golf rights as rivals Discovery snap up £2bn deal with PGA Tour for broadcast rights outside US
item.description: The PGA Tour announced the plans on Monday, which would see Discovery - the American broadcaster that also controls Eurosport - take command of all media operations outside the US.
item.content:encoded:
Sky are facing a battle to remain the UK's main broadcaster of the PGA Tour after the golfing body announced they are closing in on a £2billion deal with Discovery.

The PGA Tour announced the plans on Monday, which will see Discovery - the American broadcaster that also controls Eurosport - take command of all media operations outside the US.

Discovery have signed a deal which will begin in 2019 and run until 2030.


It is a move that has been described as 'pioneering' by the PGA Tour on their official website, as they hope to create 'an international multi-platform home for golf'. 

Since 2007, the PGA Tour has negotiated all of its non-US broadcast rights deals on its own, but the deal would see them outsource this responsibility to the global broadcaster.

It will leave Sky's current coverage of the PGA Tour at risk with their current deal set to expire in 2022, meaning it will not immediately impact their coverage. However, Discovery could make a move for the UK broadcast rights in the future.

According to the Guardian, a senior PGA Tour source confirmed that the UK market will be 'open to negotiation', but only in the future.

Sky also lost the rights to cover the US PGA Championship at Quail Hollow last year after their contract which ran for a decade was not renewed, with the organisation preferring to pursue routes that will broaden their reach.

Discovery has the potential to auction coverage on a territory‑by‑territory basis, which could see Sky make a sub-licence agreement with a direct rival or even forced to give up one of its core sports.

Sky are yet to comment on the deal, but speaking to the PGA Tour's official website, Discovery president and chief executive, David Zaslav, said: 'Today is a fantastic day for golf fans around the world as Discovery proudly partners with the PGA Tour to create something that has never been done before.'

PGA Tour commissioner, Jay Monahan, added: 'This is an exciting next step for the PGA TOUR, which presents a tremendous opportunity to accelerate and expand our media business outside the United States, better service our international broadcast partners, and drive fan growth with a deeply experienced strategic global partner.'

Discovery will be taking control of global multi-platform live rights, outside the United States, and carry broadcasts to all PGA TOUR media properties which will accumulate to up 2,000 hours of content per year and 150 tournaments annually.

The deal will see Discovery handle the rights of THE PLAYERS Championship, the FedExCup Playoffs, and the Presidents Cup.

item.title: Eddie Hearn reveals Anthony Joshua is likely to face Alexander Povetkin in his next fight despite being close to agreement with Deontay Wilder
item.description: Eddie Hearn says his 'gut feeling' is that Anthony Joshua will face Alexander Povetkin in his next fight, despite being close to an agreement with Deontay Wilder after lengthy talks.
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Joshua is close to tying up deals for his next two fights, with Alexander Povetkin increasingly likely to be his next opponent and Deontay Wilder signing up for a blockbuster in early 2019.

A fight with Wilder, the WBC champion, has long been the preferred choice for September but those plans are set to be put back as US broadcasters do not want a clash with Canelo Alvarez’s comeback fight following his drugs ban.

It has created a scenario where Povetkin, the mandatory challenger for Joshua’s WBA title, is likely to fill a September slot, with Wilder expected to contest a unification bout with Joshua in February or March. Talks with both parties have been taking place simultaneously, with deals close on each front.


There remains a chance that Wilder will be the next fight, with dates in October and November under consideration, but promoter Eddie Hearn said his ‘gut feeling’ is that Joshua will fight Povetkin in September and then face Wilder in early 2019.

He said: ‘I believe we will get a deal done with Deontay quite soon. We are close on that. Ideally AJ and us wanted September in the UK but that isn’t working for them. 

'There is a chance we could make that fight in October or November, if it was to be AJ’s next fight, or we could do it in February or March if he fights Povetkin next.

‘Either way, I think we are close to a deal. It could well be that AJ fights Povetkin in September and after that it would be Wilder in February or March. He will fight Wilder in his next two fights.

‘But my gut feeling right now is that Povetkin will be the next fight, in September.’

A fight between Povetkin and Joshua, the IBF, WBO and WBA champion, would be in Britain, with London most likely. Povetkin, the 2004 Olympic champion, has 34 wins and only one defeat against Wladimir Klitschko from 35 fights, with the most recent being a fifth-round knockout of David Price on Joshua’s undercard in March.

That unification fight with the WBC champion has now been slated for two possible windows, with dates in October and November considered, or a slot in February or March.

item.title: Sergio Ramos struts back into Spain squad with his Real Madrid Champions League winners...and lets Diego Costa know who's in charge at World Cup training camp
item.description: Players from the Champions League winners were given extra time off following their victory over Liverpool in Kiev on May 26 and Ramos joked around at the photoshoot.
item.content:encoded:
Sergio Ramos and his Real Madrid team-mates joined up with the rest of the Spain squad on Tuesday for the team photoshoot and training.

Players from the Champions League winners were given extra time off following their victory over Liverpool in Kiev on May 26.

It was revealed on Monday that Reds goalkeeper Loris Karius suffered concussion after a clash with centre-back Ramos in the final. 


It was reported in Germany he had suffered a blackout and that 26 of his 30 tests subsequently confirmed he had experienced a concussion, after medical tests and a scan in America.

The incident with Madrid’s Ramos occurred two minutes before the first of his two monumental errors. 

Liverpool fan groups were calling for a replay of the final following the revelations.

Ramos' eyes were firmly on the World Cup on Tuesday as he joked around during the photoshoot and trained ahead of the tournament. 

Ramos let Atletico Madrid striker Diego Costa know who's in charge during a playful exchange as they lined up for the camera.

The defender was also pictured speaking to former Liverpool goalkeeper Pepe Reina as well as manager Julen Lopetegui as the 23-man squad lined up in their full kit.

It has been a special two months for Andres Iniesta, too. The former Barcelona legend announced his departure after 22 years with the Catalan club, and is looking ahead to what will be his final World Cup with Spain.

And to add to his growing list of individual honours, the footballing icon was gifted the Royal Order of Sports Merit award by Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez during the session.

The Spanish PM visited the Spain squad as they limbered up for their upcoming warm-up match against Tunisia on Saturday night. He posed for a picture with the squad, holding a shirt with his name printed on the back before wishing them luck in Russia.

Lopetegui's side then kick-off their campaign in Russia with their opening Group B game against European champions and neighbours Portugal on June 15.

They then face Iran on June 20 and conclude the group stage with a match against Morocco on June 25.  

SPAIN'S GROUP B FIXTURES

vs Portugal (Friday, June 15) Fisht Olympic Stadium, 7pm

vs Iran (Wednesday, June 20) Kazan Arena, 7pm

vs Morocco (Monday, June 25) Kaliningrad Stadium, 7pm

item.title: Yaya Toure's agent warns Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola of 'African curse' after fall out with Ivorian star… and claims midfielder will play for any top six side for £1 A WEEK
item.description: Yaya Toure's agent Dimitri Seluk has warned Pep Guardiola of an 'African curse' following his client's accusation that the Manchester City boss does not like picking African footballers.
item.content:encoded:
Yaya Toure's agent Dimitri Seluk has warned Pep Guardiola of an 'African curse' following his client's sensational accusation that the Manchester City manager does not like picking African footballers.

Toure left City at the end of the season after eight trophy-laden years. But in his final campaign his relationship with Guardiola deteriorated and he made only one Premier League start.

In an interview with a French football magazine, the 35-year-old made the extraordinary suggestion that he was being discriminated against by Guardiola on racial grounds.


'Pep did everything to spoil my last season. He was cruel with me,' said Toure. 'Do you really think he could've been like that with Andres Iniesta? It got to the point I asked myself if it was because of my colour. I am not the first. Other Barcelona players asked the question.

'Maybe us Africans aren't always treated the same by certain people. When you see the problems (Pep) has often had with African players, everywhere he has been, I ask myself questions. He is too intelligent to be caught. He will never admit it. But the day he picks a team with five Africans in it, I promise I will send him a cake.' 

Now, in an lengthy interview with Russian outlet Sport24, Seluk has warned the City boss of an 'African curse' and insisted Toure would be happy to play for another club in the Premier League's top six for a lowly wage of £1 per-week.

'Yaya knows Guardiola like no other,' he said. 'He worked with him both in Barcelona and in Manchester City. With all the desire, nothing good about the human qualities of Guardiola can be said. 

'God sees everything. As a man who acted with Yaya, the legend of the club, which under different pretexts did not give the opportunity to go on the field. He turned all Africa against himself, many African fans turned away from Manchester City.

'And I'm sure that many African shamans in the future will not allow Guardiola to win the Champions League. This will be for Guardiola an African curse. Life will show whether I am right or not.'  

Toure played under Guardiola at Barcelona, winning the Champions League in 2009 as well as two league titles and a Spanish Cup. However, the two men never looked at ease with each other when Guardiola succeeded Manuel Pellegrini at City two summers ago.

Seluk bemoaned how the Spaniard first came to the Etihad Stadium and claimed he announced his arrival early purely to disrupt Pellegrini's final season at the helm.

'You can start with the fact that he came to Manchester City in a nasty manner. The transfer was announced at a time when Pellegrini, his co-worker in the coaching department, was still at the helm of the team,' he added.

'Guardiola was afraid that Pellegrini would win the championship and other tournaments that season, as he did before he came to Bayern Munich, when Jupp Heynckes won all that is possible. Guardiola could not repeat the achievements of Heynckes, being the next three years at the helm of the best German club, which without Guardiola again leads and wins. 

'What did Guardiola achieve? In two years he won the same as Mancini or Pellegrini. And Pellegrini reached the semi-finals of the Champions League, and Guardiola – not yet. Manchester City has now extended the contract with him for three years.

'I bet that Guardiola will not win the Champions League during this time, no matter how much money he has spent, but he likes to do it. When only £200million is spent on the line of defence, when money is not counted…

'Perhaps, many will say that this is the style of Guardiola, that he plays enchanting football. Only when you buy all the best players in the world, it's much easier than, for example, in the case of (Claudio) Ranieri, who won the Premier League with Leicester.'

As a free agent, Seluk insisted the veteran could still be of use to the other members of the Premier League's top six and claimed next season will be focused on proving Guardiola wrong.

'Now Yaya has many offers from different countries, where they are ready to pay a lot of money, but we decided to dedicate the next season to Guardiola. And to prove and show the fans of Manchester City that Yaya is not finished with football. He is full of energy and wants to play this season in England,' he said.

'At a time when huge sums are being spent in England for the purchase of football players, I officially declare that Yaya is ready to move as a free agent to any English club in the top six with a salary of £1 a week – but for certain successes to make a bonus system.

'I believe that a player like Yaya would not harm Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United, Tottenham and Liverpool. Yaya – the winner. And never before has a top footballer with leadership qualities harmed any club, especially when it is not necessary to pay for it.'

Manchester City declined to comment on Monday night.
item.dc:abstract: Yaya Toure's agent Dimitri Seluk has warned Pep Guardiola of an 'African curse' following his client's sensational accusation that the Manchester City manager does not like picking African footballers. Toure left City at the end of the season after eight glorious years. But in his final campaign his relationship with Guardiola deteriorated and he made only one Premier League start. In an interview with a French football magazine, the 35-year-old made the extraordinary suggestion that he was being discriminated against by Guardiola on racial grounds. Seluk warned the City boss of an 'African curse', claimed he will never win the Champions League again and insisted Toure would be happy to play for another club in the Premier League's 'Big Six' for a wage of £1 per week.
