item.title: Andy Murray reveals he's closing in on playing return in time for Wimbledon after 'very slow' rehab
item.description: MIKE DICKSON: With the SW19 tournament fast approaching, Andy Murray says he has returned to training and playing in the grass court season remains his aim after his hip injury.
item.content:encoded:
Andy Murray maintains that he is within sight of a return to competitive tennis, but that the process of recovering from hip surgery has been much more arduous than expected.

The twice Wimbledon champion confirmed what his mother Judy said on Monday that he has been able to restart practising again in recent days.

However, it must be very doubtful that he will be able to participate in next week's ATP event in Rosmalen, Holland, for which he is still officially entered.  


'I'm getting closer to playing again, I've started training a few days ago, hoping to make my comeback during the grass court season,' he said in a video to plug his car sponsor.

'It's been very slow, I've been out getting close to a year now which is a lot longer than I expected at the beginning.'

Again the 31-year-old Scot has avoided giving any specific update on how his injury is progressing, but it is clear that he is cutting it very fine in terms of making any sort of meaningful comeback in which he could be properly competitive for Wimbledon.

Murray's intention remains to play at the Fever Tree Championships at Queen's Club in London, which starts a week on Monday. Wimbledon begins a fortnight after that. 

If all had gone to plan he would have played in the Loughborough Challenger event last month, but clearly the hip has not proved as co-operative as hoped, and he had to step back from training in May.

He last hit a ball in anger at last year's Wimbledon, although he did manage to play a charity exhibition against Roger Federer in Glasgow last November when his movement was clearly compromised.

There was then a further exhibition one-set match in Abu Dhabi just after Christmas before an abortive attempt to play the Brisbane Open, after which he opted to undergo surgery in Melbourne on January 8.

item.title: Max Verstappen is soul-searching after his Monaco crash adds to growing list of mistakes, says Red Bull director Adrian Newey
item.description: Max Verstappen may appear impervious to criticism but Red Bull technical head Adrian Newey says F1's youngest race winner has been doing some soul-searching as the mistakes mount up.
item.content:encoded:
Max Verstappen may sometimes appear impervious to criticism but Red Bull technical head Adrian Newey says Formula One's youngest race winner has been doing some soul-searching as the mistakes mount up.

Verstappen, 20, has stood on the podium only once in the six races so far this season and has had two retirements-- while Australian team mate Daniel Ricciardo has won twice.

The youngster has also drawn plenty of comment and criticism for his errors.


'We're all human,' Briton Newey said at a Motorsport Hall of Fame event late on Monday.

'He can try and shrug off everybody else's comments and opinions but when you've had a run like that, you question yourself a bit. Of course you do.

'But I think he's tough enough that he'll come through that,' added Newey.

'He's had one of those bad runs. He's a great driver, he's very quick and at some point he'll shed that (poor sequence) again and be on his way,' he said.

'Part of being a racing driver is learning from your mistakes and I think he's bright enough to do that.'

MAX VERSTAPPEN'S RECORD IN FORMULA ONE 2018 

Australia - 6th

Bahrain - Retired

China - 5th

Azerbaijan - Retired

Spain - 3rd

Monaco - 9th 

Former world champion Nico Rosberg said after Monaco, where Verstappen crashed in final practice and lined up last, that he had not seemed to learn at all despite being in his fourth season.

'At the moment everything is going wrong for him but I don't have much hope for him anymore,' added the German.

Team principal Christian Horner said after the Monaco crash that Verstappen knew he had to cut out the mistakes.

'He needs to learn from it, and stop making these errors. He knows that more than anybody,' said Horner.

'For the whole team to only be running one-legged with such a strong car is frustrating.'

Verstappen finished third in Spain last month but retired in Azerbaijan after a collision with Ricciardo. In China he tangled with Mercedes's Lewis Hamilton and Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel, ending up fifth.

He also collided with Hamilton in Bahrain and retired, while in Australia he spun and finished sixth after starting fourth.

Verstappen, who has a long-term contract, will be Red Bull's main hope at this weekend's Canadian Grand Prix, with Ricciardo facing at least a 10-place grid penalty due to power unit usage.

While Montreal has long straights likely to put the Red Bull car at a disadvantage to Mercedes and Ferrari, the medium to low speed corners should be much more to its liking.

item.title: New Zealand-born Brad Shields takes part in first England training session ahead of South Africa opener as Chris Robshaw is told to 'Beat the Boks' on his birthday cake
item.description: New Zealand-born Brad Shields took part in his first England training session on Tuesday as Eddie Jones' side continue to gear up for the opening Test against South Africa this weekend.
item.content:encoded:
New Zealand-born Brad Shields took part in his first England training session on Tuesday as Eddie Jones' side continue to gear up for the opening Test against South Africa this weekend.

Shields, the Hurricanes captain and blindside flanker, has flown from New Zealand to join up with England for the first time after being included in the squad for the three-Test series against the Springboks.

However it was not all good news as Jones was confronted with another injury scare in the build-up to Saturday's first match in Johannesburg, as Joe Launchbury was unable to train.

ENGLAND'S SOUTH AFRICA TOUR SCHEDULE

First Test - June 9 (Ellis Park, Johannesburg)

Second Test - June 16 (Free State Stadium,  Bloemfontein)

Third Test - June 23 (Newlands, Cape Town) 

Jones's squad had their latest practice session on pitches next to Kings Park Stadium in Durban - where they are based for most of this tour - and Launchbury remained separate from his team-mates.

The 27-year-old Wasps lock was being taken through a series of stretching exercises while the rest of the players did drills nearby.

Exeter No 8 Sam Simmonds was also initially separate from the group, for what appeared to be a fitness test. But he later joined in with the main training session, to suggest he will be available for selection. 

The situation with Launchbury is less clear-cut and any prospect of being without him for the series opener at Ellis Park would be a significant setback for Jones. England are already without two other leading locks, Courtney Lawes and George Kruis, along with Bath rookie Charlie Ewels.

England's scrum coach, Neal Hatley, said: 'Joe has just got a small niggle on his calf and we'll see where he gets to with that. It's hard to tell how much of a doubt he is, we'll have a look at what he's done this morning. That (assessment) will be on-going.' 

If Launchbury is cleared to play, the 52-cap veteran is destined to start alongside Maro Itoje in the second row. However, if he has to be ruled out, Jones may opt to select Nick Isiekwe alongside his club-mate Itoje, even though he spent much of the latter part of the season in the Saracens back row, at blindside flanker. 

Billy Vunipola played a full part in the session after playing through Saracens' successful Aviva Premiership play-off campaign with a persistent hamstring problem. 

Harlequins flanker Chris Robshaw also celebrated his turning 32 on Monday and was presented with a cake with the words 'Beat the Boks' added in icing.

England face a difficult task when the return to Ellis Park on Saturday, the same venue they were beaten 36-27 six years ago. 

Back in 2012, under Stuart Lancaster, England were brutally battered in the Johannesburg venue where Jones' side have to front up this weekend.

Joe Marler, Ben Youngs, Chris Robshaw and Owen Farrell - captain on this tour - are the only survivors from that game and will be keen to exact revenge.

item.title: 'You're not going to criticise Lionel Messi when he walks on the pitch': Man United's Paul Pogba slams critics as he defends his relaxed playing style
item.description: France international Paul Pogba, since joining Manchester United for a then world-record fee of £89million, has come in for heavy criticism following his high-profile move in the summer of 2016.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United midfielder Paul Pogba has slammed his critics in a heated interview with France Football ahead of the World Cup.

The Frenchman, since joining United for a then world-record fee of £89million, has come in for heavy criticism following his high-profile move in the summer of 2016.

However, it isn't just club football where he is struggling. Pogba was jeered by France supporters when he was substituted against Italy last Friday night.


But Pogba, who will be looking for a successful World Cup to reinvigorate his career, has emphatically defended himself by claiming that no one ever criticises Lionel Messi 'when he's walking on the pitch'.

When asked about his relaxed style of play, the 25-year-old told France Football: 'I've always been like that. When I've won, I've won being like that. That's my style of play. 

'You're not going to criticise a Messi when he walks on the pitch. He puts three goals in and you will say "ah but he is walking on the pitch?" No. 

'You can not tell me how to play. Nobody can tell me how to play. If I'm here today, it's like I am. Nobody told me how to be. It's my football, that's all. Whether people like it or not.

'Do I need this to be loved? Do I need people to judge me differently? Or do they talk better about me?'

The former Juventus man added that he doesn't care what football fans think of him, insisting he only worries about the opinion of his loved ones. 

He said: 'I do not live for people, for what they think, for them to say that I'm nice, good, the best, perfect. Everyone has their opinion. And I respect that. I play football, I do what I like. My relatives support me. They are more important.'

Pogba, who is no longer assured of his spot in France's starting XI at the World Cup, will be eager to get off to a fast start in Russia.

Pogba and his France team-mates begin their World Cup campaign against Australia on June 16.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo already posing with team-mates as he shows off his leg muscles one day into Portugal training camp ahead of bid for World Cup glory
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo takes centre stage with his arms crossed and a stern stare down the lens - the message here: he means business this summer.
item.content:encoded:
Few rivalries run as deep as Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi and the Argentine's recent G.O.A.T - Greatest Of All Time - photoshoot was sure to have irked the Portuguese star.

So Ronaldo, never one to fade into the background, struck a pose of his own after just one day of returning to Portugal training ahead of the World Cup.

Alongside team-mates including Beto, Rui Patricio and Mario Rui, Ronaldo took centre stage with his arms crossed, shorts pulled up to show off those powerful thighs and a stern stare down the lens - the message here: he means business this summer.


The biggest criticism handed to both Ronaldo and Messi is that unlike legends of the game like Pele and Diego Maradona, neither have ever gone on to win the World Cup.

And with Ronaldo now 33 and Messi aged 30 their chances are running out fast with Russia potentially the last opportunity to have a strong assault on the biggest stage.

Ronaldo ticked one major international honour off his to-do list with Euro 2016 but with a Portugal squad lacking the quality boasted by Messi's Argentina, the pressure falls on the Real Madrid star to have the tournament of his career so far.

A World Cup win for either would provide a major boost in their attempts to be declared the Greatest Of All Time.

Ronaldo has the confidence and self assurance that he is the best but even he will have been surprised to see Messi's clever play on words in his pre-World Cup shoot. 

Wearing the Argentina home shirt for the tournament in Russia and a whole load of other merchandise supplied by sponsor adidas, Messi is pictured holding and stroking various goats.

The goats came from La Granja Natura, a Barcelona-based petting zoo, and their vets were on hand to ensure none were harmed during photography.

According to the write-up in New York-based Paper Magazine, Messi was a natural. 'I am a big fan of animals,' he said.
